revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name=Delia Green |image= |image_caption= |birth_name= |birth_date=1886 |birth_place= |death_date=December 25, 1900 (aged 14) |death_place= [[Savannah, Georgia]], U.S. |death_cause= [[Homicide]] by [[firearm]] |nationality= [[Americans|American]] |citizenship= United States |resting_place=[[Laurel Grove Cemetery|Laurel Grove Cemetery South]], Savannah, Georgia, US |occupation= |known_for= Murder victim, song inspiration }}
'''Delia Green''' (1886 – December 25, 1900)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.murderbygaslight.com/2010/03/delias-gone-one-more-round.html|title=Delia's Gone, One More Round|website=www.murderbygaslight.com|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> was a 14-year-old [[African Americans|African-American]] [[murder]] victim who has been identified as the likely inspiration for several well-known traditional [[United States|American]] songs, usually known by the titles "Delia" and "Delia's Gone".
==History== According to contemporaneous reports published in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] newspapers, Green was shot and killed by 15-year-old Mose (or Moses) Houston late on Christmas Day, 1900, in the Yamacraw neighborhood of [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah]], Georgia, after an argument earlier in the evening. Houston, the newspapers implied, had been involved in a sexual relationship with Green for several months. The shooting took place at the home of Willie West, who chased down Houston after the shooting and turned him over to the city police.
Green's murder and Houston's trial in the spring of 1901 were reported in the ''[[Savannah Morning News]]'' and the ''[[Savannah Evening Press]]''. Although Houston reportedly had confessed to the murder at the time of his arrest, at his trial he claimed the shooting was accidental. Other witnesses, however, testified that Houston had become angry after Green called him "a son of a bitch".
Houston was convicted and sentenced to life in prison, on the jury's recommendation of mercy. After serving more than twelve years, he was paroled by Governor [[John M. Slaton]] in 1913<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hauntedsavannahtours.com/delias-gone/|title=The Murder of Delia Green {{!}} Savannah True Crime Tour|date=2018-05-27|work=Haunted Savannah Tours {{!}} Savannah Ghost Tours {{!}} Walking Ghost Tours in Savannah|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref>. Accounts of his later life are sketchy, but he is said to have died in [[New York City]] in 1927 after other brushes with the law.
Green was buried in an unmarked grave in [[Laurel Grove Cemetery|Laurel Grove Cemetery South]] in Savannah.
==Songs== {{Wikisource|Delia (song)}} Songs based on Delia Green's murder became both common and popular in the next few decades. In 1928, folklorist [[Robert Winslow Gordon]] reported to the [[Library of Congress]] that he had traced the songs back to a murder in Savannah and that he had interviewed both Green's mother and the police officer who took Houston into custody.
Gordon's research was never published, and Green's relationship to the popular songs was essentially unknown until Prof. John F. Garst, working from hints left by Gordon, turned up the details in Savannah newspaper archives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://savannahnow.com/stories/062300/OPEDletters.shtml | title= Letters to the editor | work = Savannah Morning News |publisher= Savannah now |date=2000-06-23 |accessdate= 2012-10-16}}</ref>
The songs inspired by Green's murder now appear in two forms; both forms were staples of the "folk revival" of the 1950s and early 1960s. One version, usually attributed to [[Blake Alphonso Higgs]], is known as "Delia's Gone". It is explicitly told from her killer's point of view. The second version, usually attributed to [[Blind Willie McTell]], is usually known as "Delia" and is told from an ambiguous point of view.
Among the many singers who have covered "Delia" are [[Bob Dylan]] and [[David Bromberg]]. [[Josh White]] and [[Pete Seeger]] each recorded "Delia's Gone" in 1955, followed by [[Harry Belafonte]], [[Bud and Travis]], [[Burl Ives]], [[The Kingston Trio]], and other "folk revival" singers. Pat Boone had a minor hit with "Delia Gone" in 1960, with the composition attributed to Caperton Henley.
It was recorded numerous times by country singers, including [[Bobby Bare]], [[Waylon Jennings]] and [[Johnny Cash]]. In the music video for Cash's fourth recording of the song, the role of Delia was played by [[Kate Moss]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *{{Citation | first = Debora | last = Kodish | title = Good Friends and Bad Enemies: Robert Winslow Gordon and the Study of American Folksong}} *{{Citation | title = Southern Folklore Quarterly | volume = 1 | number = 4 |date=December 1937}}
==External links== *{{findagrave|58949318}} *{{Citation | first = Sean | last = Wilentz | author-link = Sean Wilentz | contribution = Delia | title = The Red Rose and The Briar | editor1-first = Sean | editor1-last = Wilentz | editor2-first = Greil | editor2-last = Marcus | editor2-link = Greil Marcus}}

revision.text:
'''Fareeda "Kokikhel" [[Afridi]]''' was a [[Pashtuns|Pashtun]] [[Feminism|feminist]], a women's rights activist in [[Pakistan]]. In July 2012, at the age of 25, she was shot dead on her way to work.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/activists-killing-reverberates-in-Pakistan/2012/07/18/gJQArR7ctW_story.html Activist’s killing reverberates in Pakistan]</ref><ref>[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/woman-ngo-worker-shot-dead-in-peshawar/1/203768.html Woman NGO worker shot dead in Peshawar]</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Yusufzai|first=Zahir|title=A Feminist, Women Rights Activist Killed|url=http://frc.com.pk/news/a-feminist-women-rights-activist-killed/|accessdate=29 October 2012|newspaper=FATA Research Centre|date=5 July 2012}}</ref>
Afridi was born and raised in the [[Khyber Agency|Khyber tribal area]], part of the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]] (FATA), an impoverished semi-autonomous region in Pakistan's northwest, bordering [[Afghanistan]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Zia|first=Asad|title=Militancy: A progressive voice for tribal women silenced in targeted attack|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/403834/militancy-a-progressive-voice-for-tribal-women-silenced-in-targeted-attack/|accessdate=8 July 2012|newspaper=The Express Tribute (with the International Herald Tribune)|date=5 July 2012}}</ref>
She graduated from university with a master's degree in [[gender studies]]. While still in school, with her sister Noor Zia Afridi, she founded the [[Society for Appraisal and Women Empowerment in Rural Areas]] (SAWERA), a women-run [[NGO]] promoting women's empowerment in FATA.<ref>{{cite web|title=About SAWERA|url=http://www.asafeworldforwomen.org/partners-in-asia/partners-in-Pakistan/sawera.html|publisher=Safe World for Women|accessdate=8 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218142715/http://www.asafeworldforwomen.org/partners-in-asia/partners-in-pakistan/sawera.html|archivedate=18 February 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>[http://tribune.com.pk/story/247182/positive-Pakistanis-sister-act/ Positive Pakistanis: Sister act]</ref>
Afridi was critical of the Pakistani government, the [[Taliban]], and the patriarchal nature of Pakistani society.<ref name="IBN">[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/359823/20120705/woman-activist-fareeda-kokikhel-shot-dead-peshawar.htm Pakistani Women's Rights Activist Fareeda 'Kokikhel' Afridi Shot Dead in Peshawar]</ref>
In June 2012, she told journalists she was being threatened. Her friends and colleagues suspected the threats originated with FATA Taliban militants.<ref name="IBN"/>
On 5 July 2012, as Afridi left her home to go to work in [[Hayatabad]] a suburb of [[Peshawar]], she was shot once in the head and twice in the neck by two motorcyclists, who afterwards escaped. She died in hospital.<ref>{{cite news|last=Crowstaff |first=Chris |title=Pakistani Women's Rights Activist Fareeda 'Kokikhel' Afridi Shot Dead in Peshawar |url=http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/blogs/the-word-on-women/Pakistani-womens-rights-activist-fareeda-kokikhel-afridi-shot-dead-in-peshawar |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130705174634/http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/blogs/the-word-on-women/Pakistani-womens-rights-activist-fareeda-kokikhel-afridi-shot-dead-in-peshawar |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 July 2013 |accessdate=8 July 2012 |newspaper=TrustLaw (Thomson Reuters) |date=7 July 2012 }}</ref>
Condemning the murder at a protest camp organized by the [[Aurat Foundation]] along with [[Peshawar Press Club]] and [[Pakistan Federal Union of Journalists]], Khyber Pakhtunkhwa's Information Minister [[Mian Iftikhar Hussain]] stated:{{quote|Imposing death decrees on individuals such as Farida has resulted in a negative portrayal of our country as well as Islam itself.<ref>[http://tribune.com.pk/story/406088/woman-activists-murder-widely-condemned/ Woman activist’s murder widely condemned]</ref><ref>[http://tribune.com.pk/story/405503/farida-afridis-murder-alliance-calls-for-timely-justice-protection-of-human-rights-activists/ Farida Afridi's murder: Alliance calls for timely justice, protection on human rights activists]</ref><ref>[http://tribune.com.pk/story/404089/hrcp-condemns-killing-of-human-rights-activist-alleged-blasphemer/ HRCP condemns killing of human rights activist, alleged blasphemer]</ref>}}
She was the second female in [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] to be targeted by Taliban extremists.<ref name="Second target">{{cite news|last=Zia|first=Asad|title=Targeting women:Malala, Taliban's third female victim|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/449931/targeting-women-malala-talibans-third-female-victim/|accessdate=20 October 2012|newspaper=The Express Tribune|date=11 October 2012}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Muslim feminists]] * [[Women in Pakistan]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox musical | name = Fiorello! | imagesize = 180px | image = Fiorello.png | caption = Original Logo | music = [[Jerry Bock]] | lyrics = [[Sheldon Harnick]] | book = [[Jerome Weidman]]
[[George Abbott]] | basis = Life of [[New York City]] mayor [[Fiorello H. La Guardia]] | productions = 1959 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]
1962 Broadway
1994 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] concert
2013 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] concert | awards = [[Tony Award for Best Musical]] (1960)
[[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] (1960) }} '''''Fiorello!''''' is a [[musical theatre|musical]] about [[New York City]] mayor [[Fiorello H. LaGuardia]], a reform [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] who took on the [[Tammany Hall]] political machine. The book is by [[Jerome Weidman]] and [[George Abbott]], drawn substantially from the 1955 volume ''Life with Fiorello'' by [[Ernest Cuneo]],[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/05/obituaries/ernest-l-cuneo-82-owned-news-service.html?pagewanted=1 "Ernest L. Cuneo, 82; Owned Newspaper Service"], ''The New York Times'', March 5, 1988. Accessed April 23, 2010. with lyrics by [[Sheldon Harnick]], and music by [[Jerry Bock]]. It is one of only nine musicals to win the [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]]. ==Productions== ''Fiorello!'' opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Broadhurst Theatre]] on November 23, 1959, moved to [[The Broadway Theatre]] on May 9, 1961, and closed on October 28, 1961,Esterow, Milton. "Bosley Can Boast A Perfect Record", ''The New York Times'', October 28, 1961, p. 12 after 795 performances. It was directed by George Abbott, with choreography by [[Peter Gennaro]]. [[Tom Bosley]] originated the title role opposite [[Howard Da Silva]] as the Republican machine boss Ben Marino. The cast featured [[Ellen Hanley]] as Thea, [[Pat Stanley]] as Dora, Patricia Wilson as Marie, [[Nathaniel Frey]] as Morris, and Broadway's future Superman, [[Bob Holiday]], as Neil. The 1962 production opened at the [[New York City Center]] on June 13, and closed after 16 performances, on June 24, 1962. The show was directed by [[Jean Dalrymple]], staged by [[Dania Krupska]], choreography by [[Kevin Carlisle]], scenery and lighting design by [[William and Jean Eckart]], costume supervision by Joseph Codori, musically directed by Jay Blackton, and press by Lilliam Libman. The cast included [[Sorrell Booke]] (Fiorello LaGuardia), [[Art Lund]] (Ben Marino), Lola Fisher (Thea), [[Dody Goodman]] (Dora), Barbara Williams (Marie), [[Paul Lipson]] (Morris), Richard France (Neil), Dort Clark (Floyd), and Helen Verbit (Mrs. Pomerantz). One of the singing ensemble included [[Rosalind Cash]]. A staged concert production of ''Fiorello!'' was performed at the first [[Encores!]] at the [[New York City Center]] concert series in February 1994. Directed by [[Walter Bobbie]], the cast featured [[Jerry Zaks]] as LaGuardia, [[Philip Bosco]] as Ben Marino, [[Faith Prince]] as Marie, and [[Elizabeth Futral]] as Thea.Holden, Stephen.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F04E6D71238F932A25751C0A962958260&scp=1&sq=Fiorello%21&st=nyt "Review/Theater; La Guardia Administration In a Dramatic Comeback",] ''New York Times'', February 11, 1994 To celebrate the 20th season of the Encores! series, ''Fiorello!'' was presented by the New York City Center Encores! as a staged concert in January 2013. With direction by Gary Griffin and choreography by Alex Sanchez, the cast starred [[Danny Rutigliano]] as La Guardia, [[Shuler Hensley]] as Marino, [[Erin Dilly]] as Marie and [[Kate Baldwin]] as Thea. The production included a new Bock/Harnick song during Act II, as part of "The Name's La Guardia" reprise.Gans, Andrew and Jones, Kenneth. [http://www.playbill.com/article/pulitzer-prize-winning-fiorello-returns-to-city-center-jan-30-new-song-added-com-202007# "Pulitzer Prize-Winning 'Fiorello!' Returns to City Center Jan. 30; "New" Song Added"] Playbill, January 30, 2013 The Berkshire Theatre Group (BTG) production of ''Fiorello!'' opened [[Off-Broadway]] at the East 13th Street Theater on September 4, 2016. Directed by Bob Moss, it received mixed reviews and ran through October 7th.Clement, Olivia. [http://www.playbill.com/article/acclaimed-fiorello-revival-to-arrive-off-broadway# "Acclaimed 'Fiorello! 'Revival to Arrive Off-Broadway"] Playbill, August 2, 2016{{cite web |last1=Clement |first1=Olivia |title=What Do Critics Think of the Fiorello! Revival? {{!}} Playbill |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/what-do-critics-think-of-the-fiorello-revival |website=Playbill |accessdate=3 November 2018 |language=en}}{{cite web |last1=Canacci |first1=Bill |title=Off-Broadway: Dated 'Fiorello!' falls flat |url=https://www.app.com/story/entertainment/theater/2016/09/19/broadway-dated-fiorello-falls-flat/90722048/ |website=Asbury Park Press |accessdate=3 November 2018 |language=en}} The BTG production first ran at The Unicorn Theatre in [[Stockbridge, Massachusetts]] in June and July 2016.Viagas, Robert. [http://www.playbill.com/article/the-names-laguardia-fiorello-musical-headed-off-broadway-this-fall# "The Name's LaGuardia: 'Fiorello!' Musical Headed Off-Broadway This Fall"] Playbill, July 6, 2016Plemmons, Chesley. [http://www.curtainup.com/fiorelloberk16.html "A CurtainUp Berkshire Review. 'Fiorello!'"] curtainup.com, accessed August 3, 2016 ==Synopsis== The story follows the life of [[Fiorello H. La Guardia]] during [[World War I]] and ten years later. As [[Mayor of New York City]] La Guardia reforms city politics by helping end [[Tammany Hall]]'s vaunted political machine. ; Act I Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia is reading the comics over the radio because there is a newspaper strike. As he does so, the time changes to 1915 and the law office where clients are eagerly waiting to speak to LaGuardia. His law clerks assure the crowd that he will help one and all, regardless of their ability to pay ("On the Side of the Angels"). Fiorello's secretary Marie and her friend Dora discuss a crisis. Thea Almerigatti, the leader of the women shirtwaist strikers, has been arrested.''Fiorello!'' c. 1960, Popular Library Edition, Random House, pp. 16, 42 LaGuardia promises to help the strikers. As the district leader Ben and his political buddies play poker ("Politics and Poker"), Marie introduces LaGuardia as a potential Congressional candidate. They want to beat the corrupt machine of Tammany Hall. While helping the women strikers, Fiorello asks Marie to dinner, but Thea, newly released from prison, arrives. She asks Fiorello to dinner to plan strategy, and he breaks his date with Marie. Marie feels foolish for caring while he cares so little ("Marie's Law"). Next year Fiorello is campaigning for Congress, and Thea introduces him. Fiorello promises to break the stranglehold of Tammany Hall ("The Name's LaGuardia!"). LaGuardia wins the election ("The Bum Won"). In another year, LaGuardia enlists in the Air Force and proposes to Thea. He and Marie say their farewells as he is about to leave for the war ("Till Tomorrow"). LaGuardia's participation in the war is presented as a series of montages, staged and on film.{{cite web |url=http://www.guidetomusicaltheatre.com/shows_f/fiorello.htm |title=Fiorello! |work=The Guide to the Musical Theatre |accessdate=December 9, 2010}} With the war over, Fiorello returns home ("Home Again"), with both Marie and Thea waiting for him. He goes to Thea, who has agreed to marriage. Morris, the office manager, comforts Marie. ; Act II In 1929 LaGuardia runs for mayor of New York, after he and Thea are married. Thea, home from a visit to the doctor, exclaims her love ("When Did I Fall In Love"). At Dora and her husband Floyd's (who has retired from the police force) home, the corrupt backers of [[Jimmy Walker]], Fiorello's competitor for mayor, meet. As one of the gang wants to have Fiorello killed at his public speech, Dora rushes to secretly warn Marie. However, Fiorello's campaign is in turmoil, with Ben being fired and his worry over Thea's deteriorating health. At LaGuardia's speech the gang's plan to kill him is foiled. But Thea dies, and Marie, Morris, and Neil have to tell Fiorello. The race for mayor is won by Jimmy Walker. Fiorello is inspired by tragedy to continue his campaign. In 1933 Ben and his political friends are again playing poker ("Little Tin Box"). Marie arrives and announces that she is quitting her job and will marry "The Very Next Man" who asks her. She convinces Ben to return to Fiorello to help him win the upcoming mayoral election. She then helps Fiorello to overcome his fears of losing and run again. He runs with Ben's help, and also asks Marie to marry him. She accepts and Fiorello finally becomes the mayor. ==Background and analysis== The musical contains several songs built around a group of machine politicians. In "Politics and Poker", Republican [[machine politics|machine politicians]] try to pick a [[United States Congress|congressional]] candidate in a district they consider hopeless, while playing a game of [[poker]], and compare politics to poker. The lyric is set to waltz tempo "to underscore the frivolity of their cynicism."Ostrow, Stuart. "Present at the Creation" (2006). Hal Leonard Corporation. {{ISBN|1-55783-646-9}}, p. 31 In "The Bum Won", these same politicians commiserate with one another after LaGuardia has won the election without their support. In "Little Tin Box", they imagine a series of Tammany politicians attempting to explain to a judge that their wealth came from their scrupulous habits of saving ("I can see Your Honor doesn't pull his punches/ And it looks a trifle fishy, I'll admit,/ But for one whole week I went without my lunches/ And it mounted up, Your Honor, bit by bit./ Up Your Honor, bit by bit.") In "I Love a Cop", woman factory worker describes her hapless situation of having fallen in love with a policeman who was called out against a [[strike action|strike]] by her [[labor union|union]]; "The Name's La Guardia" has LaGuardia campaigning in [[English language|English]], [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]].Shea, Tom. "Broadway's Most Wanted" (2004). Brassey's. {{ISBN|1-57488-596-0}}, pp. 123–124 There is also a [[ragtime]] number, "Gentleman Jimmy" about ''bon vivant'' mayor [[Jimmy Walker|James J. "Jimmy" Walker]], and the comic "Marie's Law", in which Marie proposes a "law" about how husbands should treat their wives. ("Every girl shall have a honeymoon, which will last at least a year,/ During which aforesaid honeymoon, every care shall disappear…".) Besides the invention of some peripheral characters, the musical changes some basic facts of LaGuardia's life. LaGuardia's first wife, Thea, died after only three years of marriage, but the fictional Thea lives another eight years, so that her death can be one more calamity during LaGuardia's unsuccessful 1929 mayoral campaign; also, the script downplays LaGuardia's generally successful congressional career to make him seem more of an outsider and increase the triumph of his eventual mayoral victory in 1933. ==Songs== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ; Act I * "On the Side of the Angels" * "Politics and Poker" * "Unfair" * "Marie's Law" * "The Name's LaGuardia" * "The Bum Won" * "I Love a Cop" * "I Love a Cop (reprise)" * "Till Tomorrow" * "Home Again" {{col-break}} ; Act II * "When Did I Fall in Love" * "Gentleman Jimmy" * "Gentleman Jimmy (reprise)" * "The Name's LaGuardia (reprise)" * "Little Tin Box" * "The Very Next Man" * "Politics and Poker (reprise)" * "The Very Next Man (reprise)" * "The Name's LaGuardia (reprise)" {{col-end}} An additional song, "Where Do I Go from Here?" (originally written for Marie to sing in Act I) was cut out of town; it can be heard on the [[Liz Callaway]] album ''Lost in Boston'' (Varese Sarabande VSD-5475). "Till Tomorrow" and "Unfair" were written "on spec" before Bock and Harnick were hired for the show. "Little Tin Box" was added on the road in [[Philadelphia]].Frank Kelly, [https://web.archive.org/web/20030930212826/http://www.geocities.com/bockharn/Bock_and_Harnick.html ''Unofficial'' Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick Appreciation Page], accessed January 1, 2010. ==Critical response== In his review for ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[Brooks Atkinson]] wrote: "...It is exciting; it is enjoyable and it is decent ... Jerry Bock has set ... a bouncy score ... [A]s the writer of lyrics, Sheldon Harnick is in an unfailingly humorous frame of mind ... [U]nder Mr. Abbott's invincible stage direction, the whole show comes alive with gusto ... [T]he cast could not be more winning or in better voice."Atkinson, Brooks. ''[[New York Times]]'', "Little Flower Blooms Again", November 24, 1959, p. 45 Louis Calta wrote: " 'Fiorello!' is the town's latest stage hit ... the attraction earned flowery praise from all of the New York drama critics."Calta, Louis. ''[[New York Times]]'', "Fiorello! Gets Landslide Vote", November 25, 1959, p. 19 ==Original cast album== The original cast recording of ''Fiorello!'' was made by [[Capitol Records]] on November 29, 1959, just six days after the show opened, and was released on December 14. The album debuted on [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard's'']] best-selling albums chart January 11, 1960, peaked at #7 and remained on the charts for 89 weeks. It has been reissued on CD twice, first by Capitol and then later in a much improved release on EMI's Broadway Angel label (CD #ZDM 7 65023-2). ==In popular culture== On the television show ''[[Mad Men]]'', [[Don Draper]] and his wife [[Betty Draper|Betty]] attend a showing of ''Fiorello!'' in the [[List_of_Mad_Men_episodes#Season_1_(2007)|season one]] episode [[Shoot (Mad Men)|''Shoot'']].Dean, Will. [https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2010/may/25/mad-men-season-one-episode-nine "Mad Men: season one, episode nine"] ''[[The Guardian]]'', 25 May 2010 ==Awards and nominations== ===Original Broadway production=== {| class="wikitable" width="95%" |- ! width="5%"| Year ! width="20%"| Award ! width="45%"| Category ! width="20%"| Nominee ! width="10%"| Result |- | rowspan="8" align="center"| 1960 | rowspan="7"| [[Tony Award]] | colspan="2"| [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] | {{won}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Musical|Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Musical]] | [[Tom Bosley]] | {{won}} |- | [[Howard Da Silva]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Direction of a Musical|Best Direction of a Musical]] | [[George Abbott]] | {{won}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Choreography|Best Choreography]] | [[Peter Gennaro]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Conductor and Musical Director|Best Conductor and Musical Director]] | Hal Hastings | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Scenic Design|Best Scenic Design]] | [[William and Jean Eckart]] | {{nom}} |- | colspan="3"| [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] | {{won}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{ibdb show|3539}} * [http://www.mtishows.com/show_home.asp?ID=000216 Fiorello!] at the [[Music Theatre International]] website * [http://www.tonyawards.com/p/tonys_search Tony Awards listing for 1960, Musical] * [http://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-category/218 Pulitzer Prize Winners by Category - Drama] {{Bock and Harnick}} {{Navboxes | title = Awards for ''Fiorello!'' | list = {{Pulitzer Prize for Drama 1951-1975}} {{TonyAwardBestMusical 1947-1975}} }} [[Category:1959 musicals]] [[Category:Biographical musicals]] [[Category:Broadway musicals]] [[Category:Musicals directed by George Abbott]] [[Category:Musicals inspired by real-life events]] [[Category:New York City in popular culture]] [[Category:Plays set in New York City]] [[Category:Plays set in the 20th century]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for Drama-winning musicals]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for Drama-winning works]] [[Category:Tony Award for Best Musical]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Got Talent | image = [[File:Got Talent logo.jpg|200px]] | genre = {{Plainlist| * [[Talent show]] * [[Reality television|Reality]] }} | creator = [[Simon Cowell]] | network = {{Plainlist| * [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] (UK) * [[NBC]] (U.S.) }} | picture_format = | first_aired = {{start date|df=yes|2006|6|21}} | last_aired = present | runtime = 45–110 minutes | related = ''[[The X Factor]]'' | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[SYCOtv]] * [[Thames (production company)|Thames]] * [[FremantleMedia]] }} | production_website = https://web.archive.org/web/20120824123947/http://www.fremantlemedia.com/production/Our_Brands/Got_Talent.aspx }} '''''Got Talent''''' is a British [[talent show]] [[television format]] conceived and owned by [[Simon Cowell]]'s [[Syco TV|SYCOtv]] company. It has spawned [[Spin-off (media)|spin-offs]] in over 58 countries (as of April 2014), in what is now referred to as the 'Got Talent' format, similar to that described by [[FremantleMedia]] of the [[Idols (TV series)|''Idol'']] and ''[[The X Factor]]'' formats. Unlike those shows, ''Got Talent'' showcases several artistic disciplines in addition to singing. In April 2014, the format was named the world's most successful reality TV format ever by the [[Guinness World Records]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/s107/britains-got-talent/news/a562780/got-talent-wins-guinness-world-record-is-most-successful-reality-show.html|title=Got Talent wins Guinness World Record, is most successful reality show |work=[[Digital Spy]] |date=7 April 2014 |accessdate=7 April 2014}} ==History== {{see also|America's Got Talent|Britain's Got Talent}} ''Got Talent'' was an invention by ''[[The X Factor]]'' creator [[Simon Cowell]], with comedian and talk show host [[Paul O'Grady]] producing a pilot for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] in 2005 under the provisional title ''Paul O'Grady's Got Talent''.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/paul-ogrady-i-gave-up-chance-1691840|title=Paul O'Grady: I gave up chance to host Britain's Got Talent|first=Sunday|last=People|date=4 September 2010|publisher=}} O'Grady left the network after disputes with ITV, resulting in Cowell moving the concept to the United States while he and ITV searched for a new show host.{{cite web|last1=Dowell|first1=Ben|title=O'Grady: why I left ITV|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/jan/11/broadcasting.ITV|website=theguardian|accessdate=4 October 2017}} Owing to these issues, the ''Got Talent'' franchise ended up debuting first as ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' on [[NBC]] on 21 June 2006, with judges [[David Hasselhoff]], [[Brandy Norwood]], and [[Piers Morgan]]. The show's original series was hosted by [[Regis Philbin]].{{cite web|title=‘America’s Got Talent’: Judges and hosts of ‘AGT’ through the years — Heidi Klum, Tyra Banks, Nick Cannon …|url=http://www.goldderby.com/article/2017/americas-got-talent-judges-hosts-agt-heidi-klum-tyra-banks-nick-cannon-news/|website=Goldderby|accessdate=4 October 2017}} In 2016, the judging panel consisted of [[Howie Mandel]], [[Heidi Klum]], [[Melanie Brown]], and [[Simon Cowell]], and hosted by [[Nick Cannon]], who was the presenter from 2009-2016. People Magazine, [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20678945,00.html Heidi Klum Joins America's Got Talent], 03/04/2013. From season 12 (2017), the new host of AGT is [[Tyra Banks]].{{cite web|title=‘America’s Got Talent’ Sets Tyra Banks As New Host For Season 12|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/tyra-banks-host-americas-got-talent-1202042040/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=4 October 2017}} The grand prize for the winner(s) is US$1 million, and, since season 3, a chance to headline a show on the [[Las Vegas Strip]].{{cite web|last1=Sheehan|first1=Paul|title=Who’ll win ‘America’s Got Talent’: Darci Lynne Farmer or Angelica Hale?|url=http://www.goldderby.com/article/2017/americas-got-talent-results-winner-darci-lynne-farmer-angelica-hale-agt-news/|website=Goldderby|accessdate=4 October 2017}} ''America's Got Talent'' proved extremely successful for NBC, pulling in high ratings in both total viewers and the younger 18-49 demographic. The show's initial success in America is credited with the eventual launch of the British series, and the overall global launch of the ''Got Talent'' franchise.{{cite web|last1=Mallenbaum|first1=Carly|title='America's Got Talent': Why is it a ratings winner?|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2017/08/28/americas-got-talent-ratings-winner/596169001/|website=USA Today|accessdate=4 October 2017}} ITV eventually debuted ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' on 9 June 2007 with Cowell, Morgan and [[Amanda Holden]] as judges, and [[Ant & Dec]] as hosts of the show. For series 5, Morgan stepped down due to commitments hosting ''[[Piers Morgan Live|Piers Morgan Tonight]]'' on [[CNN]], and Cowell only attended the live shows as he was busy launching ''[[The X Factor (U.S.)|The X Factor USA]]'', so [[Michael McIntyre]] and [[David Hasselhoff]] joined the panel with Holden.{{cite web|title=Piers Morgan to quit Britain's Got Talent|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/britains-got-talent/7822960/Piers-Morgan-to-quit-Britains-Got-Talent.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=5 October 2017}} In October 2011, it was confirmed that McIntyre and Hasselhoff would not return for series 6 and they were replaced by [[David Walliams]] and [[Alesha Dixon]], along with Cowell returning as a judge full-time.{{cite web|last1=Fletcher|first1=Alex|title=Michael McIntyre found 'Britain's Got Talent' "uncomfortable"|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/britains-got-talent/news/a437702/michael-mcintyre-found-britains-got-talent-uncomfortable/|website=Digitalspy|accessdate=5 October 2017}} The top prize is £250,000 (£100,000 in series 1–5 and £500,000 in series 6) and a performance at the [[Royal Variety Show]] in front of the [[British Royal Family]].{{cite web|title=BGT 2017Who won Britain’s Got Talent 2017? Tokio Myers crowned the winner of the BGT grand final|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/3695863/britains-got-talent-2017-final-winner-tokio-myers/|website=The Sun, a News UK Company|accessdate=5 October 2017}} ===Proposed global version=== In June 2010, following ''Britain's Got Talent'''s success at the [[BAFTA]] television awards, Cowell voiced his ideas regarding ''World's Got Talent'', a global version of ''Got Talent''. However, he argued that the format would not work with judges as they had all "tried to be him" in previous attempts (such as ''[[World Idol]]''), and instead proposed a commentary format, similar to that of the [[Eurovision Song Contest]].{{cite web|author=pa.press.net |url=http://tv.uk.msn.com/news/articles.aspx?cp-documentid=153672118 |title=Cowell backs global Talent contest |publisher=MSN TV (tv.uk.msn.com) |date=1999-12-31 |accessdate=2012-08-03}} During the same week, more details were announced, with Cowell explaining 20 previous winning contestants from global variations of ''Got Talent'' would be brought together at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] with himself and [[Jonathan Lopez (singer)|Jonathan Lopez]] both having roles in the show. A proposed prize of £1 million was announced, along with a projected global television audience of 300 million, and an intended airdate of 2011.{{cite news | url = http://celebrity.uk.msn.com/news/gossip/articles.aspx?cp-documentid=153683029 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100614060128/http://celebrity.uk.msn.com/news/gossip/articles.aspx?cp-documentid=153683029 | archivedate = 2010-06-14 |title = Simon Cowell planning World's Got Talent? |newspaper = Splash News (www.splashnews.com) |date = 6 July 2010 |publisher = MSN Celebrity UK}} However, Cowell halted plans for the series because it would conflict with his judging commitments with ''The X Factor USA'' and ''Britain's Got Talent'' for the years to come. In February 2014, ''The X Factor USA'' was cancelled by [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] due to low ratings and Cowell's decision to return to the [[The X Factor (UK TV series)|UK version]] of that show. There is a global version of ''Got Talent'', entitled ''Planet's Got Talent''. It can be found on YouTube, showing acts from most of the internationally spread ''Got Talent'' series. The American version will launch a spin-off series, ''[[America's Got Talent: The Champions]]'', in 2019 featuring notable contestants from ''America's Got Talent'' alongside acts from the franchises worldwide.{{cite web|last1=Haring|first1=Bruce|title=‘America’s Got Talent’ Adds Winter Championship Series To NBC Schedule|url=http://deadline.com/2018/05/americas-got-talent-adds-winter-championship-series-to-nbc-schedule-1202389461/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=12 May 2018|date=12 May 2018}} ==''Got Talent'' around the world== :{{colorbox|#90EE90}} Currently airing franchise :{{colorbox|#E0B0FF}} Franchise with an upcoming season :{{colorbox|#FEFF3F}} Franchise negotiating with production, although it is not official :{{colorbox|#FCA9A9}} Franchise no longer in production {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; font-size:95%; line-height:18px; width:100%;" |- ! style="width:50px;"| Country/region !! '''Goyol''' ({{Lang-mn|гоёл}}, ''decoration'' or ''adornment'') is an annual [[fashion]] event held in [[Ulaanbaatar]], [[Mongolia]]. It started in 1988 and the last 21st event took place on 13-15 of December 2008.<ref>The 20th event took place on 11-13, December 2007</ref> Foreign [[designer]]s and [[Model (person)|models]] participate in the show since 2000. The grand prix of Goyol-2007 was won by designer of Gobi company B. Nyamsuren, and model G. Tumenjargal was selected as the best model. At the Goyol-2008 event, the [[design]]s of 50 designers and 18 companies were featured by 15 male and 55 female models on the [[catwalk]].
== Nominations of Goyol-2008 ==
* Best abstract design – B. Nomungerel * Best ethnic design – Ts. Enhtuya * Best daily wear design – O. Bold, Torgo saloon * Best knitwear design – G. Baasandash, Lats company * Best leather and fur design – Mönhsaihan & Möngönsor, Monstick company * Best sewing design – Ts. Uyanga, Shilmel zagvar company * Best fashion house – Mongoljingoo Institute * Grand Prix – N. Solyolmaa, Goyo company * Promising model – O. Purevdulam * Photo model – J. Bayarmaa * Second prize – B. Batceceg * Best female model – M. Garvasuren * Best male model – M. Bayarjargal * Best top model – B. Alimaa * Best top model - B. Dulamsuren
== Nominations of Goyol-2009 ==
Goyol-2009 was organised on the 12-13 December 2008. It featured collections of 50 designers demonstrated by 80 models with more than 500 fashion designs. In addition to the local designers, new collections were also presented by designers from [[France]], the [[Russian Federation]] and [[Korea]].
* Top model of the Festival - O. Uyanga * Grand Prix - Alimaa, Evseg agency * Best model of the year – E. Selenge * Best fashion house – Shilmel zagvar agency * Best male model - D. Samjmyatav * Second prize - J. Munkhdalai * Second prize - J. Munkhtsatsaral * Special prize - S. Ariunbileg * Photo model - O. Purevdulam
Designers:
* Best ethnic design - D. Unubolor, Shilmel Zagvar agency * Best daily wear design – Ishdorj, University of Science and Technology * Best fantasy design - Enkh-Och, City Institute * Best sewing design – Undraa * Best knitwear design – Soninjargal, Altai Cashmere LLC * New material design - Ovdogmid, independent designer * Special prize - Ganchimeg, City Institute * Special prize - Ononbayar, Usleg Edlel Zagvar agency * Special prize - Svetlana Bakyorova, Russian Feeration
== Nominations of Goyol-2010 ==
Goyol-2010 took place on the 17-19 December 2009. Sixty models participated in the show .<ref>http://www.news.mn/news/section=home/page=index#0.2725265928626096 Ch. Uranbileg becomes top model</ref>
* Top model of the Festival - Ch. Uranbileg
== References ==
<references/> Best top model - B.Dulamsuren

{{Infobox film festival |name = Hollywood Film Festival |logo = Hollywood Film Festival logo.svg |logo_alt = Hollywood Film Festival logo |logo_size = 150px |location = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]
[[United States]] |founded = 1997 |host = |date = October |language = English }} The '''Hollywood Film Festival''' is an annual [[film festival]] which is located in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States|USA]]. ==History== The Festival was established in 1997 by author producer Carlos de Abreu and his wife, model [[Janice Pennington]].Pete Hammond, [https://deadline.com/2014/11/hollywood-film-awards-winners-list-cbs-1201284863/ 'Gone Girl' Takes Top Prize At Hollywood Film Awards; 'The Imitation Game' Leads With 4 Nods: Complete Winners List ], ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'', November 14, 2014 The Hollywood Film Festival was created to make a connection between independent filmmakers and the global creative community.Michael Haddad, ''The Screenwriter's Sourcebook: A Comprehensive Marketing Guide for Screen and Television Writers'', Chicago Review Press, 2005 [https://books.google.com/books?id=DI_fo9EnFesC&pg=PT44&dq=%22hollywood+film+festival%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Lx5nVLqkMOO-mwXVw4GoBg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22hollywood%20film%20festival%22&f=false] The Hollywood Film Festival is composed of: * Hollywood Animation Film Festival * Hollywood Comedy Film Festival * Hollywood Digital Film Festival * Hollywood Documentary Film Festival * Hollywood Horror Film Festival * Hollywood Independent Film Festival * Hollywood International Film Festival * Hollywood Kids Film Festival * Hollywood Shorts Film Festival * Hollywood World Film Festival ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://hollywoodfest.com/ Official '''Hollywood Film Festival''' website] * [https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000326/overview Overview on IMDb.com] {{Hollywood Film Festival}} {{Cinema of the United States}} {{-}} [[Category:Hollywood Film Awards|.]] [[Category:Film festivals in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Hollywood history and culture]] [[Category:October events]] [[Category:November events]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1997]] [[Category:1997 establishments in California]] {{US-film-festival-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} '''Impossibility Challenger''' is an event in which [[Amateur]]s and [[professional]]s meet, and try yourself to excel, Records and [[World Record]] set up. The event takes place in different locations each year mostly in Europe and is organized by the [[Sri Chinmoy]] Centres.<ref name = nz /><ref name=vancouver/>
== History == The event was created 1982 by Sri Chinmoy. The first events were held in [[Zurich]], Switzerland from 1982 to 1991. From 2002 to 2010 it took place close to Munich, later two times in New Zealand and one time in Hungary.<ref name = nbc /><ref name = e /> In 2014 it was in Leiria, Portugal and in November 2015 and 2016 it was held in [[Berlin]], Germany.<ref name = s /> The next holding is planned in Czech Republic on 12 November 2017.<ref name = ic />
== Extract of world records == * 2002 Agim Agushi (Kosovo) is heading a football continuously for 15 km in 3:12:29 hours * 2005 Shamita Achenbach-König sets a world record by playing Cello for 24 hours (she played over 4.000 pieces) * 2006 Vaibhava Jewgenij Kuschnow (Austria) sets a world record by holding a headstand on a driving car for 21:20 min <ref name = can /> * 2006 Milan Roskopf (Slovakia) juggles three 10kg shots for 15.8 seconds * 2008 [[Ashrita Furman]] (US) sets a world record by run the fastest mile on stilts in 7:13 min * 2008 Rainer Schröder (Germany) pulled a small truck of 7t for 28.15 metres in 1 minute with his teeth * 2008 Ralf Laue (Germany) blew a regular golf ball over a distance of 3.284 metres with one breath * 2009 Ramón Campayo (Spain) correctly memorized a 34-digit binary number in only 0.5 seconds * 2010 Ranjit Pal (India) 255 rope skips in one minute * 2010 Anavi Jenniver Davies (Canada) sets a world record by whistling 24 hours * 2014 Charuhasi Eckhard Schröder (Germany) recited 3.148 poems by heart in a period of 34 hours * 2014 Albert Walter tore a [[Phonebook]] with 1551 pages in 9.38 seconds * 2015 Belachew Girma (Ethiopia) set a world record lauging non-stop for 3 hours, 35 min and 30 seconds * 2015 Samalya Arthur Schäfer (Germany) runs the fastest mile in swim fins in 5 minues, 33 seconds * 2015 Karteek Clark (Scotland) told the most jokes in an hour: 587 * 2016 Abhinabha Tangermann (Netherlands) did the most one-hand-claps with one hand in a minute: 427 * 2016 Radek Rosa (Czech Republic) pulled a tractor with a weight of 10'075.8 tons for 20 metres in 2.025 minutes
== References == {{reflist|refs=
<ref name="can">canada.com: {{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/Gallery+Impossibility+Challenger/1718913/story.html |title= Gallery Impossibility Challenger|year=2009|accessdate=2015-12-22 }}</ref>
<ref name="nz">eventfinda.co.nz: {{cite web|url= http://www.eventfinda.co.nz/2009/nov/auckland-west/impossibility-challenger-09|title= Impossibility Challenger '09|year=2009|accessdate=2015-12-22 }}</ref>
<ref name="nbc">nbcnews.com: {{cite web|url= http://photoblog.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/10/21/14597286-impossibility-challenger-features-events-not-to-be-tried-at-home?lite|title= Impossibility Challenger features events not to be tried at home |year=2012|accessdate=2015-12-22 }}</ref>
<ref name="vancouver">vancouversun.com : {{cite web|url= http://www.vancouversun.com/Impossibility+Challenger/1718916/story.html?__lsa=bc1c-ef74 |title= Impossibility Challenger |year=2009|accessdate=2015-12-22 }}</ref>
<ref name="ic">impossibilitychallenger.com : {{cite web|url=http://impossibilitychallenger.com/propositions/|title=Propositions |year=|accessdate=2017-10-09 }}</ref>
<ref name="s">spectator.sme.sk : {{cite web|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20403323/slovak-power-jugglers-created-two-world-records.html|title=Slovak power jugglers created two world records |year=|accessdate=2017-10-09 }}</ref>
<ref name="e">emirates247.com : {{cite web|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news-in-images/world-s-weirdest-world-records-2012-10-22-1.479898|title=World's weirdest world records |year=|accessdate=2017-10-09 }}</ref>
}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |image = Stamp of Azerbaijan 394.jpg |caption = A stamp celebrating the 5th anniversary of independence |holiday_name = Independence Day |nickname = |significance = The day the Declaration of Independence was adopted by the Supreme Soviet of the [[Azerbaijan SSR]] in 1991. |observedby = {{flag|Azerbaijan}} |scheduling = same day each year |date = October 18 |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |celebrations = [[Fireworks]], Concerts, Parades |type = State }} [[File:Stamp of Azerbaijan 763.jpg|thumb|right|A stamp celebrating the 15th anniversary of independence]] The '''Independence Day of Azerbaijan''' ([[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijan]]:Azərbaycanın müstəqillik günü) is the main state holiday in [[Azerbaijan]]. This date is celebrated annually on October 18.
== Background == Violent crackdowns took place on January 19–20, 1990, which is known as Black January. On October 18, 1991, the [[Supreme Soviet of Azerbaijan SSR|Supreme Soviet of Azerbaijan]] adopted a Constitutional Act on the Declaration of Independence of Azerbaijan. The declaration confirmed by a referendum in December 1991.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.meclis.gov.az/?/az/content/70|title=Milli Məclis|website=www.meclis.gov.az|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.calend.ru/holidays/0/0/678/|title=День независимости Азербайджана|website=Calend.ru|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://anydayguide.com/calendar/1040|title=Independence Day in Azerbaijan / October 18, 2017|last=AnydayGuide|work=AnydayGuide|access-date=2017-09-24|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>http://calendr.net/holiday/1615</ref>
== See also == *[[Republic Day (Azerbaijan)]] *[[Public holidays in Azerbaijan]]
== References == <references />

{{Infobox Website | name = Internet Broadway Database | logo = IBDB logo.gif | logo_size = 300px | screenshot = Internet Broadway Database Image.jpg | screenshot_size = 250px | caption = | url = [http://www.ibdb.com/ ibdb.com] | alexa = {{Decrease}} 89,288 ({{as of|2018|10|05|alt=October 2018}})<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/ibdb.com |title=Ibdb.com Traffic, Demographics and Competitors |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher=[[Alexa Internet]] |access-date=October 5, 2018 |quote=}}</ref> | commercial = Yes | type = [[theater|Theatrical]] [[database]] | language = [[English language|English]] | registration = Optional | owner = [[The Broadway League]] | author = | launch date = November 20, 2000 | current status = Active | revenue = }}
The '''Internet Broadway Database''' ('''IBDB''') is an online [[database]] of [[Broadway theatre]] productions and their personnel. It was conceived and created by Karen Hauser in 1996 and is operated by the Research Department of [[The Broadway League]], a [[trade association]] for the [[North America]]n commercial [[theatre]] community.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ibdb.com/index.php |title=IBDB: The official source for Broadway Information |last= |first= |date= |website=Internet Broadway Database |publisher= |access-date=July 26, 2012 |quote= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725083741/http://ibdb.com/index.php |archive-date=July 25, 2012}}</ref> The website also has a corresponding app for both the IOS and Android.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ticketnews.com/2012/03/the-broadway-league-develops-ibdb-application/ |title=The Broadway League develops IBDB application |last=LaFountain |first=Kristina |date=March 15, 2012 |website=TicketNews |publisher= |access-date=July 26, 2012 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://stage-directions.com/theatre-buzz/4008-broadway-league-releases-ibdb-app-for-ios-devices.html |title=Broadway League Releases IBDB App for iOS Devices |last=Coakley |first=Jacob |date=February 15, 2012 |website=Stage Directions |publisher= |access-date=July 26, 2012 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://travelwritersmagazine.com/broadway-leagues-new-ibdb-app-for-iphone-ipad-and-ipod-touch-links-theatergoers-with-centuries-of-theater/ |title=Broadway League’s New IBDB App for iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch Links Theatergoers with Centuries of Theater |last= |first= |date=July 22, 2012 |website=TravelWritersMagazine |publisher= |access-date=July 26, 2012 |quote=}}</ref>
This comprehensive history of [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] provides records of productions from the beginnings of New York theatre in the 18th century up to today. Details include cast and creative lists for opening night and current day, song lists, awards and other interesting facts about every Broadway production. Other features of IBDB include an extensive archive of photos from past and present [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] productions, headshots, links to cast recordings on iTunes or Amazon, gross and attendance information.
Its mission was to be an interactive, user-friendly, searchable database for League members, journalists, researchers, and Broadway fans.
The League recently added Broadway Touring shows to the database for ease of tracking shows that play in theatres across the country.
It is managed by Karen Hauser, Michael Abourizk, and Mark Smith of the Broadway League.

{{Infobox Song Contest |name = Junior Eurovision Song Contest |year = 2015 |theme = ''#Discover'' |logo = Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2015 logo.png |final = 21 November 2015 |semi = |presenters = [[Poli Genova]] |exsupervisor = [[Vladislav Yakovlev (television executive)|Vladislav Yakovlev]] |exproducer = Joana Levieva-Sawyer |director = Christian Biondani
Gordon Bornello |host = [[Bulgarian National Television]] (BNT) |venue = [[Arena Armeec]], [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]] |vote = Each country/jury awards 12, 10, 8–1 points to their 10 favourite songs. |entries = 17 |null = |interval = [[Krisia Todorova|Krisia]], [[Hasan & Ibrahim]]
[[Vincenzo Cantiello]] |opening = |winner = {{Esc|Malta|Junior}}
"[[Not My Soul]]" |debut = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Australia|Junior}}|{{Esc|Ireland|Junior}}}} |return = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Albania|Junior}}|{{Esc|Macedonia|Junior}}}} |withdraw = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Croatia|Junior}}|{{Esc|Cyprus|Junior}}|{{Esc|Sweden|Junior}}}} | Green = Y | Green SA = | Purple = | Red = | Yellow = Y}} The '''Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2015''' was the thirteenth annual [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest]], and took place, for the first time, in [[Bulgaria]]. The Bulgarian national broadcaster [[Bulgarian National Television|BNT]] was the host broadcaster for the event. The final took place on 21 November 2015 and was held at the [[Arena Armeec]] in [[Sofia]]. [[Poli Genova]], a Bulgarian singer and former representative of Bulgaria in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011]] and the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]], hosted the show. A total of seventeen countries participated, with {{Esccnty|Australia|Junior}} and {{Esccnty|Ireland|Junior}} making their debuts. {{Esccnty|Albania|Junior}} and {{Esccnty|Macedonia|Junior}} returned after being absent since the {{Escyr|2012|Junior}} and {{Escyr|2013|Junior}} contests, respectively. {{Esccnty|Croatia|Junior}} and {{Esccnty|Cyprus|Junior}} withdrew after returning in the {{Escyr|2014|Junior|2014 edition}}, while {{Esccnty|Sweden|Junior}} withdrew for the first time since 2008. The winner of the contest was [[Destiny Chukunyere]], who represented Malta with the song "[[Not My Soul]]". {{Esccnty|Armenia|Junior}} and {{Esccnty|Slovenia|Junior}} finished in second and third place, respectively. This was Malta's second victory in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest, having won previously in {{Escyr|2013|Junior}}. This contest marked the second time a country won twice in a three-year period (following Belarus winning twice in a period of three years between [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2005|2005]] and [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2007|2007]]). Malta's 185-point victory also achieved the highest amount of points received by any entry in the history of the contest, beating Spain's record of 171 points set during the {{Escyr|2004|Junior|2004 edition}}. This contest also set new records for the highest amount of points for a non-winning entry with Armenia's 176 points and the highest placing and score achieved by a country without earning any 12-point scores with Slovenia's third place and 112 points. ==Location== {{location map+ |Mediterranean |relief=yes |width=225|float=left |caption=Locations of the bidding countries. The eliminated countries are marked in red. The chosen host country is marked in blue.|places= {{location map~|Mediterranean |lat=41.9 |long=12.5 |label=[[Rome]]|position=left|mark=Red pog.svg}} {{location map~|Mediterranean |lat=35.897778 |long=14.5125 |label=[[Valletta]]|position=left|mark=Red pog.svg}} {{location map~|Mediterranean |lat=42.7 |long=23.33 |label='''[[Sofia]]'''|position=right|mark=Blue pog.svg}} }} [[File:Арена Армеец София.jpg|thumb|225px|left|Arena Armeec, in Sofia. Venue for the 2015 Junior Eurovision.]] ===Bidding phase=== Following {{Esccnty|Italy|Junior}}'s win at the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014, the European Broadcasting Union had given the Italian broadcaster [[RAI]] the [[Right of first refusal|first refusal]] to host the 2015 contest.{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Italy: Discussions on hosting will begin Monday|url=http://eurovoix.com/2014/11/15/italy-discussions-on-hosting-will-begin-monday/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=19 January 2015|date=15 November 2014}} However, on 15 January 2015, RAI declined the right to host the contest. The Executive Supervisor for the Junior Eurovision Song Contest, [[Vladislav Yakovlev (television executive)|Vladislav Yakovlev]], praised the Italian broadcaster RAI for their time looking into the possibilities of hosting, even though they made their debut appearance in 2014, and further explained how the EBU were in a lucky position to have received bids from two countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=junior_eurovision_2015_two_countries_interested_in_hosting|title=Junior Eurovision 2015: Two countries interested in hosting|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|last=Fisher|first=Luke James|accessdate=15 January 2015|date=15 January 2015}} The EBU announced later that day that they had received bids from two countries to host the contest; those countries being {{Esccnty|Bulgaria|Junior}} and last year host {{Esccnty|Malta|Junior}},{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=JESC’15: Italy will not host, 2 countries interested|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/01/15/jesc15-italy-will-not-host-2-countries-interested/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=19 January 2015|date=15 January 2015}} who finished in second and fourth places respectively in 2014.{{cite web|last1=Ross|first1=Samantha|title=Breaking News: Italy wins!|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=breaking_news_italy_wins|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=19 January 2015|date=15 November 2014}} Bulgarian broadcaster BNT confirmed on 15 January they had submitted a bid to host the 2015 contest.{{cite web|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/01/15/bulgaria-jesc-2015-bid-confirmed/|title=Bulgaria: JESC 2015 Bid Confirmed|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=16 January 2015|date=15 January 2015}} The national broadcaster for Malta, [[Public Broadcasting Services]] (PBS), stated prior to the 2014 contest that they would host again if they won.{{cite web|url=http://eurovoix.com/2014/11/11/jesc14-malta-will-host-in-2015-if-they-win-again/|last=Granger|first=Anthony|title=JESC’14: Malta will host in 2015 if they win again|accessdate=19 January 2015|date=11 November 2014|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix}} On 26 January 2015, it was announced that Bulgaria had been chosen to host the 2015 edition, which took place on 21 November 2015.{{cite web|last1=Lockett|first1=Katherine|title=Junior Eurovision 2015: 21 November in Sofia, Bulgaria|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=junior_eurovision_2015_21_november_in_sofia_bulgaria|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=30 March 2015|date=30 March 2015}} It was the first time that the nation organised any [[Eurovision (network)|Eurovision event]].{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Bulgaria to host Junior Eurovision 2015|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/01/26/bulgaria-to-host-junior-eurovision-2015/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=26 January 2015|date=26 January 2015}} In March 2015, it was confirmed that Sofia would be the host city, with the Arena Armeec being the host venue. ==Format== ===Graphic design=== [[File:JESC 2015 stage.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Arena Armeec stage during the 2015 Junior Eurovision.]] On 22 May 2015, a press conference devoted to the Junior Eurovision Song Contest was held in [[Vienna]] during the organisation of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015]]. At the press conference, the slogan for the 2015 Junior contest was revealed to be ''#Discover''. The slogan was selected to signify how the Junior Eurovision Song Contest endeavours to find new melodies, explore new people and create links between individuals.{{cite web|title=#Discover е темата на Детската Евровизия 2015|url=http://eurovision.bnt.bg/hashtag-discover-e-temata-na-detskata-evrovisia-2015/|website=BNT|publisher=BNT|accessdate=23 November 2015|date=22 May 2015|language=Bulgarian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304051456/http://eurovision.bnt.bg/hashtag-discover-e-temata-na-detskata-evrovisia-2015/|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} On 23 June 2015, the EBU in conjunction with the host broadcaster BNT, presented the official logo for the 2015 edition, during the Steering Group meeting held in Sofia.{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Luke James|title=Presenting the 2015 logo!|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=presenting_the_2015_logo|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=30 June 2015|date=23 June 2015}} Viara Ankova, the Director General of the host broadcaster explained that the logo's concept was inspired behind the idea of a seeded head of a [[dandelion]] being blown, "something that everyone has done as a child".{{Pull quote|text=The logo shows how Bulgaria’s young people are the seeds of the future; venturing out from the safety of tradition to explore and discover a new future for themselves and for us all.|author=Viara Ankova, General Director of BNT}} The postcards used to introduce each competing nation during the show were built around the concept of [[selfies]].{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Luke James|title=Postcard Concept - Selfies!|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=postcard_concept_-_selfies|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=23 November 2015|date=14 October 2015}} The postcards featured the competing artists sending their selfie to a group of three teenagers in Bulgaria, which would then inspire their adventures. Different sights and cities were showcased with the teenagers documenting their journey through their own selfies and sending them to the competing artist. ===Host=== [[File:Poli Genova at JESC 2015.jpg|thumb|Poli Genova, host]] Bulgarian singer [[Poli Genova]] was announced as the host of the competition on 21 October 2015.{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Luke James|title=Meet your host... Poli Genova!|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=meet_your_host..._poli_genova|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=21 October 2015|date=21 October 2015}} Genova had previously represented Bulgaria at the Eurovision Song Contest in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011|2011]]. In addition, the running order draw and opening ceremonies were hosted by Bulgarian singer Joanna Dragneva, who had also previously represented Bulgaria at the Eurovision Song Contest in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008|2008]] as part of [[Deep Zone Project]].{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Luke James|title=Opening Ceremony: Sunday at 19:30 CET live from the NDK|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=opening_ceremony_sunday_at_1930_cet_live_from_the_ndk|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=23 November 2015|date=12 November 2015}} ==Participating countries== On 7 October 2015, it was confirmed that seventeen countries would take part in the contest. {{Esccnty|Australia|Junior}} and {{Esccnty|Ireland|Junior}} made their debut, {{Esccnty|Albania|Junior}} returned after a [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2012|two-year absence]] and {{Esccnty|Macedonia|Junior}} returned after a [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2013|one-year absence]]. {{Esccnty|Croatia|Junior}} and {{Esccnty|Cyprus|Junior}} withdrew after returning in the 2014 edition, while {{Esccnty|Sweden|Junior}} withdrew for the first time since [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2008|2008]]. It was the first time since [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2007|2007]], that 17 countries would take part.{{cite web|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=australia_joins_to_make_it_super_17_at_junior_eurovision_in_sofia|title=Australia joins to make it 'Super 17' at Junior Eurovision in Sofia!|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|last=Fisher|first=Luke James|accessdate=7 October 2015|date=7 October 2015}} ===Results=== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! pesma]]" | [[Serbia in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2015#Lena Stamenković|Lena Stamenković]] | 499 |- |} ==Other countries== {{Further|List of countries in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest}} For a country to be eligible for potential participation in the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest]], it needs to be an active member of the [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU).{{cite web|title=Junior Eurovision Song Contest steering group|url=http://www3.ebu.ch/sites/ebu/contents/programming/tv/tv-groups/junior-eurovision-song-contest-s.html|publisher=EBU|date=23 January 2014|accessdate=26 May 2014|last=Yakovlev|first=Vladislav|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528005833/http://www3.ebu.ch/sites/ebu/contents/programming/tv/tv-groups/junior-eurovision-song-contest-s.html|archivedate=28 May 2014|df=}} It is unknown whether the EBU issue invitations of participation to all 56 active members like they do for the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. The [[European Broadcasting Union#Members|EBU Active Members]] listed below have made the announcements regards their decisions. ===Active EBU members=== *{{Esc|Cyprus|Junior}} – On 29 June 2015, the national broadcaster of Cyprus, [[Cyprus Broadcasting Corporation]] (CyBC), revealed that they would not participate in the 2015 contest due to lack of funds.{{cite web|last=Granger|first=Anthony|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/29/jesc15-cyprus-withdraws/|title=JESC’15: Cyprus Withdraws|publisher=Eurovoix.com|accessdate=29 June 2015|date=29 June 2015}} *{{Esc|France|Junior}} – [[France 2]] announced on 24 June 2015 that they had no plans to return to the contest, however the broadcaster sent a delegation to Bulgaria in order to observe the 2015 edition.{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=France: No Return To Junior Eurovision In 2015|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/24/france-no-return-to-junior-eurovision-in-2015/|website=eurovoix.com|date=24 June 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=France: Is Looking At Returning To Junior Eurovision|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/11/18/france-is-look-at-returning-to-junior-eurovision/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=18 November 2015}} *{{Esc|Germany|Junior}} – [[Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen]] (ZDF) were observers at last year's contest.{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Germany: NDR has not ruled out JESC 2015 début|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/02/germany-ndr-has-not-ruled-out-jesc-2015-debut/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=27 June 2015|date=2 June 2015}} On 2 June 2015, [[Norddeutscher Rundfunk]] (NDR) stated that they had not ruled out a début in the 2015 contest. On 1 July 2015, [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]] consortium member NDR launched an online poll to decide whether or not Germany should participate in Junior Eurovision, which would be broadcast on their children's station, [[KiKa]] (which is a joint venture of ARD and ZDF).{{cite web|last1=Feddersen|first1=Jan|title=Germany: Deutschland beim Junior Eurovision Song Contest?|url=http://www.eurovision.de/feddersens_kommentar/Deutschland-beim-Junior-Eurovision-Song-Contest,jesc102.html|website=eurovision.de|publisher=NDR|accessdate=1 July 2015|date=1 July 2015}} Germany was originally on the list of participants for the inaugural contest{{cite web|title=The first ever "Eurovision Song Contest for Children" is born |url=http://www.ebu.ch/en/union/news/archives/2002/press_song_contest_kids.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060905112912/http://www.ebu.ch/en/union/news/archives/2002/press_song_contest_kids.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 September 2006 |accessdate=1 August 2015 |date=21 November 2002 }} and again in 2004 but later withdrew.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/2853/germany_withdraws_from_junior_eurovision_song_contest/ |title=Germany withdraws from Junior Eurovision Song Contest|website=Esctoday.com|publisher=Esctoday|last=Philips|first=Roel|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304130209/http://esctoday.com/2853/germany_withdraws_from_junior_eurovision_song_contest/|archive-date=4 March 2016|date=8 June 2004|accessdate=1 August 2015}} The debut of the country in the competition didn't materialize. However, on 4 November 2015, it was announced that NDR would broadcast a livestream of the contest on their Eurovision website for the first time.{{cite web|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/11/04/germany-livestream-for-jesc-2015/|title=Germany: Livestream For JESC 2015|website=Esctoday.com|publisher=Esctoday|date=4 November 2015|accessdate=4 November 2015}} *{{Esc|Greece|Junior}} – [[Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation]] (ERT) stated on 11 June 2015 that they were undecided about returning to the Junior contest but are "willing to examine interesting projects".{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Greece ERT returns to air|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/11/greece-ert-returns-to-air/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=27 June 2015|date=11 June 2015}} However, the country was not among the 2015 edition's list of participants. *{{Esc|Romania|Junior}} – On 4 June 2015, Televisiunea Românâ ([[Romanian Television|TVR]]) revealed that due to lack of interest, Romania's participation in the 2015 contest would be unlikely.{{cite web|last=García|first=Belén|title=Junior Eurovision : Romanian participation unlikely|url=http://www.esc-plus.com/junior-eurovision-romanian-participation-unlikely/|website=esc-plus.com|publisher=ESC+Plus|accessdate=4 June 2015|date=4 June 2015}} *{{Esc|Spain|Junior}} – Several media outlets reported that [[Televisión Española]] (TVE) was working on returning to the contest in 2015. However, these claims were not confirmed by the broadcaster.{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Spain TVE to return to Junior Eurovision?|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/05/spain-tve-to-return-to-junior-eurovision/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=''Eurovoix''|accessdate=5 June 2015|date=5 June 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Morales|first1=Víctor|title=TVE estudia su vuelta al Festival de Eurovisión Junior|url=http://www.formulatv.com/noticias/46766/tve-estudia-vuelta-festival-eurovision-junior-eurojunior-2016/|website=formulatV.com|publisher=FormulaTV|accessdate=6 June 2015|language=Spanish|date=6 June 2015}} Ultimately the country was not among the 2015 edition's list of participants. *{{Esc|Sweden|Junior}} – [[Sveriges Television]] (SVT) announced on 29 June 2015 that the broadcaster would withdraw from the contest for one year to focus on new youth-focused projects and hosting the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]].{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Sweden to take a year off from Junior Eurovision|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/29/sweden-to-take-a-year-off-from-junior-eurovision/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=29 June 2015|date=29 June 2015}} The following broadcasters publicly declined to participate in the contest without providing any further explanations: {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} *{{Esc|Austria|Junior}} – [[Österreichischer Rundfunk|ORF]]{{cite web|last=Granger|first=Anthony|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/03/21/austria-no-jesc-debut-in-2015/|title=Austria no JESC début in 2015|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=''Eurovoix''|accessdate=2 July 2015|date=21 March 2015}} *{{Esc|Belgium|Junior}} – [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]{{cite web|last=Granger|first=Anthony|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/23/belgium-ketnet-will-not-return-to-junior-eurovision-in-2015/|title=Belgium: Ketnet Will Not Return To Junior Eurovision In 2015|publisher=Eurovoix.com |accessdate=23 June 2015|date=23 June 2015}} and [[RTBF]]{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Belgium: RTBF will not return to Junior Eurovision in 2015|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/26/belgium-rtbf-will-not-return-to-junior-eurovision-in-2015/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=27 June 2015|date=26 June 2015}} *{{Esc|Croatia|Junior}} – [[Croatian Radiotelevision|HRT]]{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Croatia withdraws from Junior Eurovision|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/23/croatia-withdraws-from-junior-eurovision/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=''Eurovoix''|accessdate=2 July 2015|date=23 June 2015}} *{{Esc|Czech Republic|Junior}} – [[Česká televize|ČT]]{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Czech Republic will not debut at JESC 2015|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/03/19/czech-republic-will-not-debut-at-jesc-2015/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=19 March 2015|date=19 March 2015}} *{{Esc|Estonia|Junior}} – [[Eesti Rahvusringhääling|ERR]]{{cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2015/07/30/estonia-err-debut-junior-eurovision-2015/100412/|last=Lee Adams|first=William|title=Estonia: ERR confirms it will not debut at Junior Eurovision 2015|website=wiwibloggs.com|publisher=Wiwibloggs|accessdate=30 July 2015|date=30 July 2015}} *{{Esc|Finland|Junior}} – [[Yle Fem]]{{cite web|last1=Fasting|first1=Claus Michael|title=Finland: YLE Fem will not be participating in Bulgaria |url=http://junioreurosong4ever.weebly.com/home/finland-yle-fem-will-not-be-participating-in-bulgaria |website=junioreurosong4ever.weebly.com |publisher=JE4E |date=4 June 2015}} *{{Esc|Iceland|Junior}} – [[RÚV]]{{cite web|title=Junior Eurovision 2015: Iceland and Lithuania decline participation|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2015/06/01/junior-eurovision-2015-iceland-lithuania-participation/97238/|website=wiwibloggs.com|publisher=Wiwibloggs|accessdate=25 July 2015|date=1 June 2015}} *{{Esc|Latvia|Junior}} – [[Latvijas Televīzija|LTV]]{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=Latvia no return to Junior Eurovision in 2015|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/03/16/latvia-no-return-to-junior-eurovision-in-2015/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=16 March 2015|date=16 March 2015}} *{{Esc|Lithuania|Junior}} – [[Lithuanian National Radio and Television|LRT]] *{{Esc|Switzerland|Junior}} – [[Radiotelevisione svizzera|RSI]]{{cite web|last=Granger|first=Anthony|title=Switzerland: RSI Will Not Participate In JESC 2015|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/06/03/switzerland-rsi-will-not-participate-in-jesc-2015/|work=Eurovoix|publisher=[[Radiotelevisione svizzera|RSI]]|accessdate=3 June 2015|date=3 June 2015}} *{{Esc|United Kingdom|Junior}} – [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=United Kingdom: ITV will not return to Junior Eurovision|url=http://eurovoix.com/2015/03/17/united-kingdom-itv-will-not-return-to-junior-eurovision-2/#comment-13732/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=17 March 2015|date=17 March 2015}} {{div col end}} ===Non-active EBU members=== In August 2014, executive supervisor Vladislav Yakovlev said that they are working on finding a way to allow commercial networks to participate in the contest, although they are not EBU members.{{cite web|last=Zarb|first=Noel|title=Junior Eurovision 2014: Non-EBU Member Countries Joining?|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2014/08/30/junior-eurovision-2014-non-ebu-member-countries-joining/59415/|publisher=wiwibloggs|date=30 August 2014}}{{cite web|last=Yakovlev|first=Vladislav|title=#AskVlad : About the participating countries of JESC 2014|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4MeGkm0SFes|publisher=Youtube.com|date=30 August 2014}} *{{Esc|Spain|Junior}} – Because Spanish broadcaster EBU member, [[Televisión Española]] (TVE), has declined invitations to participate since 2007, the European Broadcasting Union TV Committee will discuss in the coming months the possibility to allow commercial channels to take part in the contest.{{cite web|last=Granger|first=Anthony|url=http://eurovoix.com/2014/09/28/spain-private-channel-for-jesc-2014-not-possible/|title=Spain: Private Channel For JESC 2014 Not Possible|publisher=Eurovoix.com|accessdate=24 November 2014|date=28 September 2014}} If the final decision is yes, they will continue negotiating with Spanish private TV channels to bring back Spain to the contest.{{cite web|last=Pérez |first1=Lluis |url=http://www.ahoramundotv.es/espana-festival-eurojunior-regreso-2015/131700 |title=¿Volverá España al Festival de Eurojunior en 2015? |publisher=Ahoramundotv.es |date=17 November 2014 |language=spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220202707/http://www.ahoramundotv.es/espana-festival-eurojunior-regreso-2015/131700/ |archivedate=20 December 2014 |df= }} ==International broadcasts and voting== The order in which each country announced their votes was in the order of performance. Details of the running order were published by the EBU on 15 November 2015. The spokespersons are shown below alongside each participating country.{{cite web|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=meet_the_spokespersons_of_tonights_grand_final|title=Meet the spokespersons of tonight's Grand Final!|last=Juhász|first=Ervin|work=Junior Eurovision Song Contest – Bulgaria 2015|accessdate=21 November 2015}} ===Voting and spokespersons=== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} # [[File:Flag of None.svg|24px]] {{Esccnty|Kids Jury|Junior}} – [[Krisia Todorova]] (Bulgarian representative at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Serbia}} – Dunja Jeličić (Serbian representative at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2016|JESC 2016]]) # {{Flagu|Georgia}} – [[Lizi Pop]] (Georgian representative at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Slovenia}} – Nikola Petek # {{Flagu|Italy}} – [[Vincenzo Cantiello]] (Italian representative and the winner of the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Netherlands}} – [[Julia van Bergen]] (Dutch representative at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Australia}} – Ellie Blackwell # {{Flagu|Ireland}} – Anna Banks # {{Flagu|Russia}} – Sofia Dolganova # {{Flagu|Macedonia}} – Aleksandrija Čaliovski # {{Flagu|Belarus}} – Valeria Drobyshevskaya # {{Flagu|Armenia}} – [[Elizabeth Danielyan|Betty]] (Armenian representative at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Ukraine}} – Sofia Kutsenko (Ukrainian representative as part of [[Sympho-Nick]] at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Bulgaria}} – Vladimir Petkov # {{Flagu|San Marino}} – Arianna Ulivi (Sammarinese representative as part of [[The Peppermints]] at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Malta}} – [[Federica Falzon]] (Maltese representative at [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]]) # {{Flagu|Albania}} – Majda Bejzade # {{Flagu|Montenegro}} – [[Lejla Vulić]] (Montenegrin representative at the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2014|JESC 2014]], along with Maša Vujadinović) {{div col end}} ===Commentators=== The contest was broadcast online worldwide through the official Junior Eurovision Song Contest website junioreurovision.tv and [[YouTube]]. The online broadcasts featured commentary in English by junioreurovision.tv editor Luke Fisher and 2011 Bulgarian Junior Eurovision Song Contest entrant [[Ivan Ivanov (singer)|Ivan Ivanov]].{{cite web|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=tonight_junior_eurovision_song_contest_2015|title=Tonight: Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2015!|last=Fisher|first=Luke James|work=Junior Eurovision Song Contest – Bulgaria 2015|date=21 November 2015|accessdate=21 November 2015}} ====Participating countries==== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *{{Flagu|Albania}} – [[Andri Xhahu]] ([[Radio Televizioni Shqiptar|TVSH]], RTSH Muzikë and Radio Tirana){{cite web|first=Niko|last=Lako|title=Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2015 Finalja e 21 Nëntorit në RTSH në komentin e Andri '''''Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2015: Bulgaria''''', is a compilation album put together by the European Broadcasting Union, and was released by [[Universal Music Group]] on 13 November 2015. The album features all the songs from the 2015 contest.{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Luke James|title=Official album out now|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=official_album_-_out_now|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=17 November 2015|date=13 November 2015}}{{cite November 2015|quote=Track listing}} This is the first Junior Eurovision album to only be released digitally, as well as the first since the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2005]] not to include
