page.title: List of Broadway shows that have held the title of longest-running show

revision.comment: /* top */[[WP:AWB/GF|General fixes]] and manual cleanup, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: first debuted → debuted
revision.text:
{{See also|List of the longest-running Broadway shows}} [[File:Majestic Theatre.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' has been running at the [[Majestic Theatre (Broadway)|Majestic Theatre]] on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] since 1988.]] This is a list of shows that have held the title of being the longest-running show (including straight plays and musicals) on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] since 1853. A few probable longest-running plays prior to 1853 are also listed. Not included below is the 1976 revival of the revue ''[[Oh! Calcutta!]]'', which briefly overtook ''[[A Chorus Line]]'' as the Broadway show which had played the most performances, even though ''A Chorus Line'' had opened more than a year earlier and was still playing. ''Oh! Calcutta!'' achieved this distinction by playing more than the standard eight performances per week.{{cite news |last1=Rich |first1=Frank |authorlink1=Frank Rich |title=Critic's Notebook; The Asterisks of 'Oh! Calcutta!' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/08/theater/critic-s-notebook-the-asterisks-of-oh-calcutta.html |accessdate=2015-12-19 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=1989-08-08}} ''A Chorus Line'' retook the record for most performances after ''Oh! Calcutta!'' closed. The longest running [[off-Broadway]] musical to date is ''[[The Fantasticks]]'', which starred Jerry Orbach. When it closed on January 13, 2002, it had run for 42 years and 17,162 performances, making it the world's longest-running musical. The only other musical to come close is The Phantom of the Opera, which opened in 1988 and played its 10,000th performance in 2012.[http://time.com/3657605/fantasticks-history/ The World’s Longest-Running Musical Started Small — and Stayed Small] '''M''' denotes a [[musical theatre|musical]] and '''P''' denotes a [[straight play]]. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="font-size:96%;" |- ! Took lead ! Title ! Type ! Opening
date ! Closing
date ! Performances ! Comments/Notes |- | align="center"|2006-01-09January 9, 2006(6 January 2006). [http://www.today.com/id/10739059/ns/today-today_entertainment/t/phantom-set-outlive-cats/#.U1VN3vL_TTo ‘Phantom’ set to outlive ‘Cats’], Associated Press | ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' | align="center"| '''M''' | 1988-01-26January 26, 1988 | | 12,710{{ibdb title|4491|The Phantom of the Opera}} | '''Currently running''' at the [[Majestic Theatre (Broadway)|Majestic Theatre]]
7 [[Tony Award]]s in 1988, including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]]
7 [[Drama Desk Award]]s in 1988
Broadway's longest-running show and musical |- | align="center"|1997-06-19June 19, 1997(19 June 1997). [https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/theater/with-6138-lives-cats-sets-broadway-mark.html With 6,138 Lives, 'Cats' Sets Broadway Mark], ''[[The New York Times]]'' | ''[[Cats (musical)|Cats]]'' | align="center"| '''M''' | 1982-10-07October 7, 1982 | 2000-09-09September 10, 2000 | 7,485{{ibdb title|4186|Cats}} | 7 [[Tony Award]]s in 1983, including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]]
3 [[Drama Desk Award]]s in 1983
[[Grammy Award for Best Musical Show Album|Grammy Award for Best Cast Show Album]] in 1984 |- | align="center"|1983-09-29September 29, 1983rothstein, Mervyn (30 April 1990). [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/30/theater/after-15-years-15-a-chorus-line-ends.html After 15 Years (15!), 'A Chorus Line' Ends], ''[[The New York Times]]'' | ''[[A Chorus Line]]'' | align="center"| '''M''' | 1975-07-25July 25, 1975 | 1990-04-28April 28, 1990 | 6,137{{ibdb title|3752|A Chorus Line}} | 9 [[Tony Award]]s in 1976, including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]]
5 [[Drama Desk Award]]s in 1976, including [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Musical|Outstanding Musical]]
A [[Special Tony Award]] in 1984 for becoming Broadway's longest-running musical
[[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] in 1976
Revival in 2006 (759 performances) |- | align="center"|1979-12-08December 8, 1979(8 December 1979). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19791208&id=n8QsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OxMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7099,1942341 'Grease' hits top of Broadway list], ''Associated Press'' | ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'' | align="center"| '''M''' | 1972-02-14February 14, 1972 | 1980-04-13April 13, 1980 | 3,388{{ibdb title|3641|Grease}} | 2 [[Drama Desk Award]]s in 1972
Revivals in 1994 (1,505 performances) and 2007 (554 performances) |- | align="center"|1972-06-17June 17, 1972(19 June 1972). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19720619&id=PaIyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nOwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2314,1173751 Fiddler on the Roof longest running show], ''Ottawa Citizen'' (Associated Press) | ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]'' | align="center"| '''M''' | 1964-09-22September 22, 1964 | 1972-07-02July 2, 1972 | 3,242{{ibdb title|3213|Fiddler on the Roof}} | Became longest running musical in July 1971, at 2,845 performances passing 2,844 mark of ''[[Hello, Dolly! (musical)|Hello Dolly!]].(21 July 1971). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1893&dat=19710721&id=DGofAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CtUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5289,2089566 'Fiddler on the Roof' longest run musical on Broadway], Associated Press 9 [[Tony Award]]s in 1965, including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]]
A [[Special Tony Award]] in 1972 for becoming Broadway's longest-running musical
Revivals in 1976 (167 performances), 1981 (53 performances), 1990, (241 performances), 2004 (781 performances), and 2015 (431 performances) |- | align="center"|1947-06-14June 14, 1947(13 June 1947). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19470613&id=yj4aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KSUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4450,6595972 'Life With Father' - A Broadway Record], ''The Milwaukee Journal'' | ''[[Life with Father]]'' | align="center"| '''P''' | 1939-11-08November 8, 1939 | 1947-07-12July 12, 1947 | 3,224{{ibdb title|1720|Life with Father}} | Broadway's longest-running straight play. Started at [[Empire Theatre (41st Street)|Empire Theatre]], moved to the [[Bijou Theatre (Manhattan)|Bijou Theatre]] in 1945, and finished up its run in 1947 at the [[Alvin Theatre]]. |- | align="center"|1939-06-01June 1939(18 November 1939). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19391118&id=t7NQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=USIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2627,4710465 If Any Record Is Left, Play Breaks It Tonight], ''Milwaukee Journal'' (reporting that on November 18, 1939, ''Tobacco Road'' had 2,533rd performance, beating 2,532 mark that was being used as record for ''Abie's Irish Rose'', though it had been discovered that number included over 200 non-Broadway performances, so that record had been made 5 months prior) | ''[[Tobacco Road (play)|Tobacco Road]]'' | align="center"| '''P''' | 1933-12-04December 4, 1933 | 1941-05-31May 31, 1941 | 3,182{{ibdb title|1065|Tobacco Road}} | Revivals in 1942 (34 performances), 1943 (66 performances), and 1950 (7 performances) |- | align="center"|1925-05-23May 23, 1925(24 May 1925). [https://www.nytimes.com/1925/05/24/archives/-abies-irish-rose-makes-record-run-its-1292d-performance-one-more.html 'Abie's Irish Rose' Makes Record Run. Its 1,292d Performance, One More Than "Lightnin'," Is America's Highest Score], ''[[The New York Times]]'' | ''[[Abie's Irish Rose]]'' | align="center"| '''P''' | 1923-05-23May 23, 1923 | 1927-10-1October 1, 1927 | 2,327{{ibdb title|1064|Abie's Irish Rose}} | Revivals in 1937 (46 performances) and 1954 (20 performances) |- | align="center"|1920-03-17March 17, 1920(18 March 1920). [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1920/03/18/118310266.pdf Lightnin' Breaks Record. Reaches 658th Performance, Eclipsing Long Run of Hoyt Farce], ''[[The New York Times]]''(May 1920). [https://books.google.com/books?id=BKPNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA730&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false ], ''Munsey's Magazine'', p. 730 (" 'Lightnin' has now broken the record of 'A Trip to Chinatown' for the longest consecutive New York run ...")[https://books.google.com/books?id=vjcrAQAAIAAJ&q=%22trip+to+chinatown%22+ Theatre Week] (1990) (noting that at start of World War I, A Trip To Chinatown still held the record, which was beat by ''Lightnin'' after the war) | ''[[Lightnin' (play)|Lightnin']]'' | align="center"| '''P''' | 1918-08-26August 26, 1918 | 1921-08-27August 27, 1921 | 1,291{{ibdb title|8725|Lightnin' }} | Revival in 1938 (54 performances) |- | align="center"|1893-06-22June 22, 1893(July 1893). [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1854/06/19/76438848.pdf Uncle Tom's Cabin (advertisement)], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (announcing revival of play "as performed at the National Theatre 325 consecutive times") |- | align="center"|1850-01-011850 | ''[[The Drunkard]]'' | align="center"| '''P''' | 1850-01-011850 | 1850-10-07October 7, 1850? | 100[https://books.google.com/books?id=MDYKYNXgKB4C&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q&f=false The Drunkard as a Drama of the Temperance Movement], p. 3 (1995) | As of October 7, 1850, it hit 100 consecutive performances in New York, the first play to do so.[https://books.google.com/books?id=UAYG6Hz10RMC&pg=PA108&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false Culture, Genre, and Literary Vocation: Selected Essays on American Literature], p. 108 (2001) At [[Barnum's American Museum]]. If ''Mazeppa'' ran 43 nights in 1833 and was previous record, ''Putnam'' became most performed on its 44th performance on September 24, 1844. |- | align="center"|1833-08-091833 | ''[[Mazeppa (Byron)|Mazeppa]], Or, The Wild Horse of Ukraine'' | align="center"| '''P''' | 1833-06-22July 22, 1833 | 1833-09-09September 9, 1833 | 43Granqvist, Raoul. [https://books.google.com/books?id=9BtTGywIS7EC&pg=PA170&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false Imitation as Resistance: Appropriations of English Literature in Nineteenth-Century America], p. 170 (stating that ''Mazeppa'' ran at the Bowery Theatre for 48 consecutive nights) | At the [[Bowery Theatre]] with [[George Gale (aeronaut)|George Gale]] as Mazeppa.(31 August 1833). [http://fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2010/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Post/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Post%201833%20May-Oct%201833%20Grayscale/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Post%201833%20May-Oct%201833%20Grayscale%20-%200441.pdf Amusements], ''New York Evening Post'', p. 3, col. 5 (advertisement stating that evening will be 35th presentation of ''Mazeppa'')(9 September 1833). [http://fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2010/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Post/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Post%201833%20May-Oct%201833%20Grayscale/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Post%201833%20May-Oct%201833%20Grayscale%20-%200465.pdf Amusements], p. 3, col. 5 (announcing that Mazeppa will be performed that night "For the Benefit of Mr. Gale", appears to have been final consecutive performance){{cite journal|last1=Shank|first1=Theodore J.|title=Theatre for the Majority: Its Influence on a Nineteenth Century American Theatre|journal=Educational Theatre Journal|date=1959|volume=11|issue=3|pages=188–199|doi=10.2307/3204801|jstor=3204801}} See p. 196, noting that ''Mazeppa'' had 43 performances; ''Elephant of Siam'' and the ''Water Witch'' in 1831 had 18 each. |- | align="center"|1831-01-281831 | ''The Elephant of Siam and the Fire Fiend'' by [[Samuel Beazley]] | align="center"| '''P''' | 1831-01-10January 10, 1831 | 1831? | 18 | At the [[Bowery Theatre]], the first season under [[Thomas S. Hamblin]], who embraced melodramas which might support longer runs. ''The Elephant of Siam'' featured the elephant [[Mademoiselle D'Jeck]], who of course needed to be used while available. ''The Water Witch'', an adaption of a [[James Fenimore Cooper]] novel by [[Charles W. Taylor]], which debuted on March 10, 1831 at the Bowery, also played for 18 performances. |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Broadway theatre]]

[[File:Morricone at United Nations HQ.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Ennio Morricone at the [[United Nations Headquarters]] on 2 February 2007]] This is a list of live performances by [[film score]] composer, orchestrator, conductor and former trumpet player [[Ennio Morricone]]. He composed and arranged scores for more than 500 film and television productions.<ref>[http://www.moviemusicuk.us/fatelesscd.htm Movie Music UK, Review] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115044841/http://www.moviemusicuk.us/fatelesscd.htm |date=January 15, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enniomorricone.org/ |title=Ennio Morricone.org Biography |publisher=Enniomorricone.org |accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref>
Advised to study composition, Morricone specialized in playing trumpet in the late 40s and supported himself by playing in various jazz bands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pytheasmusic.org/morricone.html |title=Morricone at Pytheas Center for Contemporary Music|publisher=pytheasmusic.org|accessdate=2013-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e0NYYHWtz6sC&pg=PA336 |title=The Invisible Art of Film Music: A Comprehensive History|publisher=Scarecrow Press|accessdate=2013-09-29}}</ref> From 1964 up to their eventual disbandment in 1980, Ennio Morricone was the trumpet player of ''[[Gruppo di Improvvisazione Nuova Consonanza]]'' (G.I.N.C.), a group of composers who performed and recorded [[avant-garde]] free improvisations. The Rome-based avant-garde ensemble was dedicated to the development of [[improvisation]] and new music methods. The ensemble functioned as a laboratory of sorts, working with anti-musical systems and noise techniques in an attempt to redefine the new music ensemble and explore "New Consonance." Morricone played a key role in The Group and was among the core members in its revolving line-up; in addition to serving as their trumpet player, he directed them on many occasions and they can be heard on a large number of his scores from the 1970s.<ref>[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/gruppo-di-improvvisazione-nuova-consonanza-mn0001409455 Gruppo di Improvvisazione Nuova Consonanza, Biography, Allmusic, Sylvie Harrison, Retrieved January 24, 2013]</ref>
Ennio Morricone has conducted many orchestras worldwide. He is serving as one of the main conductors of the [[Orchestra Roma Sinfonietta]] since the mid-90s. He has conducted over 300 concerts worldwide and is still performing regularly.
The composer performed in such prestigious venues as the [[Great Hall of the People|Great Hall]] in Beijing, the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly Hall of the UN]] in New York City, the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London, the [[Moscow Kremlin|Kremlin]] in Moscow and [[Verona Arena|the Arena di Verona]]. Morricone made his American debut in 2007 at [[Radio City Music Hall]].
This list includes only performances by Ennio Morricone as conductor of his film music and classical works.

revision.comment: Kirkegaard is mentioned in a number of RSes on the story and is pivotal to its controversy as a 'eugenics conference' due to his far-right views.
revision.text:
The '''London Conference on Intelligence''' (LCI) is an invitation-only conference for research on controversial aspects of [[human intelligence]], including [[race and intelligence]] and [[eugenics]]. Founded in 2014, it was secretly held in the Pearson Building at [[University College London]] (UCL) in [[London]], [[England]], on four separate occasions.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/ucl-launches-investigation-secret-eugenics-conference |title=UCL launches investigation into secret eugenics conference |date=2018-01-11 |work=Times Higher Education |access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref> It was hosted by Dr. James Thompson, an honorary UCL senior lecturer in psychology.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Science |first=American Association for the Advancement of |date=2018-01-19 |title=News at a glance |url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/359/6373/256 |journal=Science |language=en |volume=359 |issue=6373 |pages=256–257 |doi=10.1126/science.359.6373.256 |issn=0036-8075 |pmid=29348213}}</ref> The existence of the conference, as well as the names of some of the attendees, was revealed by the ''[[London Student]]'' on January 10, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/51323/title/Secret-Eugenics-Conference-Uncovered-at-University-College-London/ |title=Secret Eugenics Conference Uncovered at University College London |last=Daley |first=Jim |date=2018-01-12 |work=The Scientist |access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref> In a statement released in response to news of the conference, UCL said that it had been unaware that the conference had occurred on its campus, and that the speakers there "were not approved or endorsed by UCL". Their statement also said that "We are an institution that is committed to free speech but also to combatting racism and sexism in all forms." The UCL also announced that it would investigate whether the organizers breached the University's as well as the circumstances that led to awarding of an honorary senior lectureship to Thompson.<ref>{{Cite press release |title=UCL statement on the London Conference on Intelligence |date=2018-01-10 |url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/news-articles/0118/100118-UCL-statement-on-London-conference-on-intelligence |access-date=2018-05-15 |website=www.ucl.ac.uk}}</ref>
LCI was hosted in the city of Skanderborg, Denmark, in May 2018. A local news team had the opportunity to interview [[Helmuth Nyborg]], where he made the statement: "We don't trust the media", as a reason why he alone would be interviewed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hsfo.dk/oestjylland/Bandlyst-fra-universiteterne-Hemmelig-forskergruppe-moedes-i-Skanderborg/artikel/168645|title=Bandlyst fra universiteterne: Hemmelig forskergruppe mødes i Skanderborg|date=2018-05-14|access-date=2018-05-17|language=da}}</ref>
==UCL investigation== The LCI was investigated in January 2018 following the 2017 attendance of [[Toby Young]] (who was then involved in controversy over his past tweets and tenure on the board of the government-funded [[Office for Students]]) at these conferences, as well as their alleged [[eugenicist]] content, [[neo-Nazi]] links and clandestine nature.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bennett |first1=Rosemary |title=University College London under fire over its conferences on 'eugenics' |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/university-college-london-under-fire-over-its-conferences-on-eugenics-qq5z9vvgk |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Times |date=11 January 2018 |subscription=y}}</ref><ref name="LondonStudent">{{cite news |last1=Van Der Merwe |first1=Ben |title=Exposed: London eugenics conference's neo-Nazi links |url=http://londonstudent.coop/exposed-london-eugenics-conferences-neo-nazi-links/ |accessdate=8 September 2018 |work=London Student}}</ref> Young later resigned over the controversy.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Adams |first1=Richard |title=Toby Young quits New Schools Network, citing media pressure |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/mar/23/toby-young-quits-new-schools-network-citing-media-pressure |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=23 March 2018}}</ref>
Thompson hosted the event without informing senior university officials. In response to an investigation by ''[[London Student]]'' revealing that the conference had taken place on UCL's campus, UCL announced it would be investigating how a conference on eugenics was able to occur on their campus without the university's knowledge. A UCL spokesperson told ''[[the Guardian]]'' that "UCL is investigating a potential breach of its room bookings process for events"; UCL also revoked Thompson's approval to organize future conferences.<ref name=guardian/><ref name="LondonStudent" /> The UCL issued a press release saying that it would investigate the circumstances that led to awarding of an honorary senior lectureship to Thompson, and reaffirmed that it is committed to combating racism.<ref>{{Cite press release |title=UCL statement on the London Conference on Intelligence |date=2018-01-10 |url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/news-articles/0118/100118-UCL-statement-on-London-conference-on-intelligence |language=en |access-date=2018-05-15 |website=www.ucl.ac.uk}}</ref>
In response to the controversy, the journal ''[[Intelligence (journal)|Intelligence]]'' published a correspondence defending the conference authored by 15 of its attendees. The editorial disputed that the LCI was a eugenics conference, saying that, among the 75 presentations given there over four years, only two had been on the topic of eugenics.<ref name=woodley>{{Cite journal |last=Woodley of Menie |first=Michael A. |last2=Dutton |first2=Edward |last3=Figueredo |first3=Aurelio-José |last4=Carl |first4=Noah |last5=Debes |first5=Fróði |last6=Hertler |first6=Steven |last7=Irwing |first7=Paul |last8=Kura |first8=Kenya |last9=Lynn |first9=Richard |date=July 2018 |title=Communicating intelligence research: Media misrepresentation, the Gould Effect, and unexpected forces |url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0160289618300837 |journal=Intelligence |doi=10.1016/j.intell.2018.04.002 |issn=0160-2896}}</ref> One of the authors of the editorial, psychologist [[Aurelio José Figueredo]], was subsequently reported to be the only academic receiving funding from the [[Pioneer Fund]], which is associated with [[scientific racism]] and eugenics. Figueredo told the [[Associated Press]] that the conference was not about eugenics, and that its overall theme could not be represented "by a few presentations".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://apnews.com/a9791e6174374437b3bbe17af8b76215 |title=APNewsBreak: University accepted $458K from eugenics fund |last=Kunzelman |first=Michael |date=2018-08-25 |work=AP News |access-date=2018-09-03}}</ref>
==Attendees== Notable attendees of at least one of the conferences include: *White nationalist blogger Emil Kirkegaard<ref name=guardian>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/jan/10/ucl-to-investigate-secret-eugenics-conference-held-on-campus |title=UCL to investigate eugenics conference secretly held on campus |last=Rawlinson |first=Kevin |date=2018-01-11 |work=The Guardian |access-date=2018-05-15 |last2=Adams |first2=Richard}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=van der Merwe |first1=Ben |title=It might be a pseudo science, but students take the threat of eugenics seriously |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/education/2018/02/it-might-be-pseudo-science-students-take-threat-eugenics-seriously |accessdate=21 October 2018 |work=New Statesman |date=19 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Yorke |first1=Harry |title=UCL launches 'eugenics' probe after it emerges academic held controversial conference for three years on campus |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2018/01/10/ucl-launches-eugenics-probe-emerges-academic-held-controversial/ |accessdate=21 October 2018 |work=The Telegraph |date=10 January 2018}}</ref> *[[Edward Dutton (anthropologist)|Edward Dutton]]<ref name=woodley/> *[[Aurelio Figueredo]]<ref name=woodley/> *[[Paul Irwing]]<ref name=woodley/> *[[Richard Lynn]], a British psychologist, who attended the 2017 conference.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/white-supremacists-eugenics-conference-london-778581 |title=White supremacists held secret eugenics conference at prominent London university for years |date=2018-01-11 |work=Newsweek |access-date=2018-05-15 |language=en}}</ref> *[[Gerhard Meisenberg]]<ref name=woodley/> *[[Edward M. Miller]]<ref name=woodley/> *[[Jan te Nijenhuis]]<ref name=woodley/> *[[Helmuth Nyborg]], a Danish psychologist, who attended in 2015 and 2016.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://londonstudent.coop/exposed-london-eugenics-conferences-neo-nazi-links/ |title=Exposed: London’s eugenics conference and its neo-Nazi links |date=2018-01-10 |work=The London Student |access-date=2018-08-02 |language=en-GB}}</ref> *[[Heiner Rindermann]]<ref name=woodley/> *[[Toby Young]], a British journalist, who also attended the 2017 conference. After the ''London Student'' revealed his involvement with the conference, he resigned from his positions as director of the [[Office for Students]] and a member of the [[Fulbright Commission]].<ref name=guardian />
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://londonstudent.coop/exposed-london-eugenics-conferences-neo-nazi-links/ Exposed: London’s eugenics conference and its neo-Nazi links] *[http://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/news-articles/0118/100118-UCL-statement-on-London-conference-on-intelligence UCL statement on London Conference on Intelligence]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox election | country = Moldova | type = presidential | ongoing = no | previous_election = Moldovan presidential election, November–December 2009 | previous_year = 2009 | election_date = 2 December 2011, 11 January and 16 March 2012 | next_election = Moldovan presidential election, 2016 | next_year = 2016 | turnout = | image1 = [[File:Nicolae_Timofti_June_2014_(cropped).jpg|150px]] | nominee1 = '''[[Nicolae Timofti]]''' | party1 = Independent (politician) | electoral_vote1 = 62 | percentage1 = 61.4% | title = President | before_election = [[Marian Lupu]]
(''Acting'') | before_party = Democratic Party of Moldova | after_election = [[Nicolae Timofti]] | after_party = Independent (politician) }} {{Politics of Moldova}} A '''presidential election''' was held in [[Moldova]] on 16 December 2011. The [[President of Moldova|president]] is elected by the [[Parliament of Moldova|parliament]] in an [[indirect election]]. After the election on 16 December failed, a second attempt was made on 15 January 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.actmedia.eu/top+story/the+republic+of+moldova+%3A+marian+lupu,+the+chairman+of+the+parliament+and+the+interim+head+of+the+state,+and+vlad+filat+%96+premier+/31394 |title=The republic of moldova : marian lupu, the chairman of the parliament and the interim head of the state, and vlad filat – premier |publisher=Actmedia.eu |accessdate=16 March 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/moldovan_parties_discuss_presidential_compromise/24438053.html |title=Moldovan Leaders Talk Compromise On President |publisher=Rferl.org |date=30 December 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2012}} However, that vote was annulled as being unconstitutional since it had not been held in a [[secret vote]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/12012012-moldova-presidential-election-postponed/|title=Moldova Presidential Election Postponed|date=12 January 2012|publisher=}} On 16 March,{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/moldova_parliament_election/24507831.html |title=Moldovan Parliament Sets Presidential Election For March 16 |publisher=Rferl.org |date=7 March 2012 |accessdate=16 March 2012}} parliament elected [[Nicolae Timofti]] as president by 62 votes out of 101, with the PCRM boycotting the election, putting an end to a political crisis that had lasted since [[Moldovan parliamentary election, April 2009|April 2009]].[[Washington Post]], [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/moldova-elects-pro-european-judge-timofti-as-president-ending-3-years-of-political-deadlock/2012/03/16/gIQAl3s8FS_story.html Moldova elects pro-European judge Timofti as president, ending 3 years of political deadlock] ==Background== After the [[Moldovan parliamentary election, April 2009|parliamentary election held on 5 April 2009]], the [[Party of Communists of the Republic of Moldova|PCRM]] won 49.48% of the vote and 60 seats, one seat too few to elect a President. [[Vladimir Voronin]], up to then president, was elected [[President of the Moldovan Parliament|Speaker of Parliament]] and also retained the presidency with an [[Acting President of Moldova|interim status]]. Protests and riots by opposition activists amidst [[2009 Moldova civil unrest|civil unrest]] followed in April 2009. PCRM were then unable to secure one additional vote during the [[Moldovan presidential election, May–June 2009|May–June 2009 presidential election]] out of the 41 MPs from the three opposition parties; a snap parliamentary election was necessary. The [[Moldovan parliamentary election, April 2009|parliamentary election of July 2009]] led to the PCRM losing further seats to a [[Alliance for European Integration|coalition of opposition parties]] which gained 53 seats. However, the opposition also failed to obtain enough seats to elect a president, thereby producing more uncertainty. Voronin announced on 2 September that he intended to resign, saying that his position as acting president had become "ambiguous and doubtful."[http://www.rferl.org/content/Acting_Moldovan_President_Voronin_Reportedly_Resigns/1812942.html "Voronin Resigns As Acting Moldovan President"], [[Radio Free Europe|Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]], 2 September 2009. He resigned on 11 September,{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-09/11/content_12038359.htm|title=Moldovan acting president resigns|date=11 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2009|publisher=Xinhua News Agency}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sofiaecho.com/2009/09/11/783284_last-stop-moldovas-former-president-resigns|title=Last stop: Moldova's former president resigns|date=11 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2009|work=[[The Sofia Echo]]}} sending a letter to the parliamentary secretariat.{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/9/11/apworld/20090911172506&sec=apworld|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005091725/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/9/11/apworld/20090911172506&sec=apworld|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 October 2009|title=Moldovan president Vladimir Voronin resigns|date=11 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2009|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] (Malaysia)}} By a vote of 52 MPs, the post of the President of the Republic of Moldova was declared vacant. Therefore, in accordance with Article 91 of the [[Constitution of Moldova (1994)|constitution]], which provides that "the responsibility of the office shall devolve ad interim to the President of Parliament or the [[Prime Minister of Moldova|Prime Minister]], in that order of priority," [[Mihai Ghimpu]] became the [[interim President of the Republic of Moldova]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/12/world/europe/12briefs-Moldova.html|title=Moldova: Communists to End Rule|date=11 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2009|work=The New York Times}} The [[Constitutional Court of Moldova]] confirmed earlier on 17 September, the legitimacy of [[Mihai Ghimpu]]'s position as [[Acting President of Moldova]], which gave him the right to nominate a prime minister. On the same day, Ghimpu signed a decree nominating [[Vlad Filat]] for the office of prime minister. The [[Commission for constitutional reform in Moldova]] was set up under presidential decree on 1 December in order to resolve the [[constitutional crisis]]. The post of Acting President passed later{{Why?|date=March 2012}} to [[Marian Lupu]], who held it since 30 December 2010.{{Or|date=January 2012}} ==Calendarisation== Following an interrogation submitted by four deputies of the [[Party of Communists of the Republic of Moldova|PCRM]],{{cite web |url=http://constcourt.md/RO/05_activitate_jurisdictionala/sesizari/parvenite/2011/3b_24.01.2011.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722170608/http://constcourt.md/RO/05_activitate_jurisdictionala/sesizari/parvenite/2011/3b_24.01.2011.pdf |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Moldova's Constitutional Court ruled on 8 February 2011 that the parliament is the only institution which can decide when to hold a new presidential election, since the two-month deadline after the end of the mandate of the previous president, as foreseen by the [[Constitution of Moldova|constitution]] as having expired.{{cite web|url=http://www.unimedia.info/?mod=news&id=29687 |title=Curtea Constituțională: Parlamentul va decide când va fi ales șeful statului | UNIMEDIA – portalul de ştiri nr. 1 din Moldova |publisher=Unimedia.info |date=8 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2012}} On 20 October 2011 the Moldovan parliament decided to hold a presidential election on 18 November 2011.{{cite web|author=Kommentar posten |url=http://derstandard.at/1318726413341/Neuer-Anlauf-fuer-Praesidentenkuer |title=Neuer Anlauf für Präsidentenkür – Moldau – derStandard.at " International |publisher=Derstandard.at |accessdate=16 March 2012}} ==Candidatures== On 4 November 2011, [[Igor Dodon]] announced that he would quit the Party of Communists along with MPs [[Zinaida Greceanii]] and [[Veronica Abramciuc]]. Dodon said that the three of them would vote for a president who was independent from any party, alliance or other political body.{{cite web |url=http://emoldova.net/politics/formercommunistMPs.htm |title=Former Communist MPs offer three votes to elect Moldovan president |publisher=Emoldova.net |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120709032132/http://emoldova.net/politics/formercommunistMPs.htm |archivedate=9 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} They did so due to the PCRM's to boycott the election, thus making it virtually possible to break the impasse by reaching an agreement with the majority coalition that lacks two votes to pass the election threshold.{{cite web |author=Source: reuters // Reuters |url=http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/news/moldova-defections-may-break-impasse-on-president |title=Moldova defections may break impasse on president – TrustLaw |publisher=Trust.org |date=4 November 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120917230821/http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/news/moldova-defections-may-break-impasse-on-president |archivedate=17 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Nevertheless, on 15 November the deadline for candidates' applications expired with no applications provided.{{cite web|url=http://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/20111115035441.shtml |title=Выборы президента Молдавии не состоятся из-за отсутствия кандидатов. – Новости дня – РосБизнесКонсалтинг |language=Russian |publisher=Rbc.ru |accessdate=16 March 2012}} The country's laws do not make provision for a situation where there are no presidential candidates, but the elections are likely to be postponed or cancelled. Under Moldovan law, the presidential election can be repeated only once. If the second attempt fails, the country must hold early parliamentary elections.[http://www.rferl.org/content/moldova_presidential_election/24391440.html RFE-RL], 16 November 2011 Following two failed rounds to elect a president, the AEI had two candidates: [[Veronica Bacalu]], the former Deputy Governor of the [[National Bank of Moldova]], who is working at the [[World Bank]] and was nominated by the Liberal Democrat Party; and [[Ion Ababii]], the former Minister of Health who was nominated by the Democratic Party.{{cite web |url=http://politicom.moldova.org/news/two-candidates-for-moldovas-presidential-elections-228644-eng.html |title=Two candidates for Moldova’s presidential elections |publisher=Politicom.moldova.org |date=25 February 2012 |accessdate=16 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415071726/http://politicom.moldova.org/news/two-candidates-for-moldovas-presidential-elections-228644-eng.html |archivedate=15 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }} In the end, the head of the [[Supreme Magistrate Council]] Judge [[Nicolae Timofti]] became the compromise candidate. He said that he would maintain "strategic ties" with the United States, Russia and Germany, as well as worth towards settling the dispute of [[Transnistria]]; and he added that "Moldova must become a bridge between East and West from which it can only win."{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/world/detail/124382/#ixzz1pH0Lm6Vs |title=Kyiv Post. Independence. Community. Trust – World – Moldova makes new bid to elect president, tension high |publisher=Kyivpost.com |accessdate=16 March 2012}} ==Election== Following successive failures to elect a president, the country had an acting president for over 900 days. A 60% vote was required to approve a president. According to Article 80 of the constitution: "The President of Moldova takes office on the oath-taking day and his term has a duration of 4 years." ===First attempt=== [[File:Marian Lupu Senate of Poland.JPG|thumb|150px|[[Marian Lupu]]]] On 2 December, an attempt was set for 16 December to try to get candidates for the election. At the same time, an electoral law revision was passed that asserted an election will only be held if there are any candidates and only if at least 61 MPs are present at the vote. Should the election again be unsuccessful, an early parliamentary election would have to be held (which would be the third such election after 2009 and 2010).{{cite web|author=Kommentar posten |url=http://derstandard.at/1322531790658/Dritter-Versuch-zur-Wahl-des-Praesidenten-am-16-Dezember |title=Dritter Versuch zur Wahl des Präsidenten am 16. Dezember – Moldau – derStandard.at " International |publisher=Derstandard.at |accessdate=16 March 2012}} The three PCRM MPs who defected attended the vote (with the other PCRM MPs boycotting again), but voted against Marian Lupu, who was the only candidate. Another attempt was set for 15 January 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,15606728,00.html |title=Moldova fails to choose a new president | Europe | DW.DE | 16.12.2011 |publisher=Dw-world.de |accessdate=16 March 2012}}{{cite web|author=Associated Press 2011-12-17 12:09 am |url=http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/etn/news_content.php?id=1789730 |title=Moldova fails to elect president – Taiwan News Online |publisher=Taiwannews.com.tw |date=17 December 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2012}} However, Lupu announced he would not run in the election, and stated that the governing parties were prepared to nominate a compromise candidate. ===Second attempt=== In December 2011, the Sierra Leone-born [[John Onoje]] signed up to run for president.[[Amnesty International]], [http://livewire.amnesty.org/2012/02/21/a-racist-moldova/ A racist Moldova?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104062938/http://livewire.amnesty.org/2012/02/21/a-racist-moldova/ |date=4 November 2013 }}{{cite web |url=http://social.moldova.org/news/moldovan-communist-politician-made-racist-statements-publicly-228547-eng.html |title=Moldovan Communist politician made racist statements publicly |publisher=Social.moldova.org |date=20 February 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102080814/http://social.moldova.org/news/moldovan-communist-politician-made-racist-statements-publicly-228547-eng.html |archivedate=2 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://arena.md/?go=news&n=9739&t=Dezam%C4%83gire_pentru_John_Onoje___risc%C4%83_s%C4%83_pice_examenul_la_cet%C4%83%C8%9Benie |title=Dezamăgire pentru John Onoje – riscă să pice examenul la cetățenie |publisher=Arena.md |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120707045823/http://arena.md/?go=news&n=9739&t=Dezam%C4%83gire_pentru_John_Onoje___risc%C4%83_s%C4%83_pice_examenul_la_cet%C4%83%C8%9Benie |archivedate=7 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://bucharestherald.com/politics/34-politics/28508-african-man-runs-for-president-of-moldova-wants-unity-with-romania |title=African man runs for president of Moldova, wants unity with Romania |publisher=Bucharestherald.com |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120710181548/http://bucharestherald.com/politics/34-politics/28508-african-man-runs-for-president-of-moldova-wants-unity-with-romania |archivedate=10 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} On 9 December, Onoje passed the medical examination in order to run for president. Onoje's campaign was so well publicised that the PSRM's [[Victor Șelin]] proposed revoking his Moldovan citizenship on this basis.{{cite web|author=Un articol de: Gheorghe Budeanu |url=http://www.timpul.md/articol/john-onoje-stiu-ca-rusii-au-ocupat-acest-teritoriu-in-1812-29940.html |title=John Onoje: "Ştiu că ruşii au ocupat acest teritoriu în 1812" |publisher=Timpul.md |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012}}{{cite web|author=Un articol de: Moni Stănilă Contactează autorul |url=http://www.timpul.md/articol/cum-sa-devii-vizibil-in-rm--29567.html |title=Cum să devii vizibil în RM |publisher=Timpul.md |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2012}} On 11 January, [[Oazu Nantoi]] told the press that he would run as a candidate and that he had discussed this prospect with Vlad Filat and other leaders of the Alliance for European Integration: "Their reaction was moderately positive. I remain an optimist and I hope that I will secure the parliamentary deputies' support and go ahead with my self-nomination." The same day, the PCRM had proposed the former chairman of the [[National Bank of Moldova]] [[Leonid Tălmaci]] as a compromise candidate.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/russia/detail/120372/ |title=Moldova remains without presidential candidate so far |publisher=Kyivpost.com |accessdate=18 March 2012}} The two candidates then registered with the head of the election commission to run for the post of president.{{cite web |url=http://bsanna-news.ukrinform.ua/newsitem.php?id=18836&lang=en |title=Deadline for submitting registration documents for presidential election expires today |publisher=Bsanna-news.ukrinform.ua |date=12 January 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120707214707/http://bsanna-news.ukrinform.ua/newsitem.php?id=18836&lang=en |archivedate=7 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} On 12 January, the [[Constitutional Court of Moldova]] annulled the inconclusive December election because some members of parliament violated the law by showing how they marked their ballots on television.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2012/01/12/Court-throws-out-Moldovan-presidental-vote/UPI-40701326396294/?spt=hs&or=tn |title=Court throws out Moldovan presidential vote |publisher=Upi.com |date=12 January 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012}}[[Radio Free Europe]], [http://www.rferl.org/content/moldova_delays_presidential_vote_in_parliament/24450195.html Moldova Delays Presidential Vote In Parliament] ====Aftermath==== A new [[Moldovan constitutional referendum, 2012|constitutional referendum]] was announced to be planned for April, with the presidential election to be held afterwards. On 15 January, the leaders of AEI made a joint statement announcing that a constitutional referendum would be held in April. Prime Minister Vlad Filat said that "a referendum on the amendment of the constitution will be initiated in order to give people the opportunity to rectify the constitutional deficiencies that have been triggering endless political crises." Acting President [[Marian Lupu]] added that: "Moldova's president will be elected within a month after the validation of the referendum's outcome." Liberal leader [[Mihai Ghimpu]] then said that the amendment to the constitution is the only solution to the political crisis.[[Moldpres]], [http://www.moldpres.md/News.aspx?NewsCod=379 Moldovan ruling alliance wants to amend constitution via referendum][[Jurnal de Chişinău]], [http://www.jurnal.md/ro/news/aie-ini-iaza-un-referendum-na-ional-pentru-modificarea-constitu-iei-214748/ AIE inițiază un referendum național pentru modificarea Constituției!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120140608/http://www.jurnal.md/ro/news/aie-ini-iaza-un-referendum-na-ional-pentru-modificarea-constitu-iei-214748/ |date=20 January 2012 }} The leaders of AEI then withdrew their proposal for the referendum during a special address on ''[[Moldova 1]]'' on 10 February. It added that a date for a new presidential vote would be announced on 16 February at the opening of the parliamentary session.{{cite web |author=Armenia Azerbaijan Belarus Georgia Moldova Ukraine |url=http://www.easternpartnership.org/daily-news/2012-02-13/moldova-scraps-plans-hold-constitutional-referendum |title=Moldova scraps plans to hold a constitutional referendum |publisher=Easternpartnership.org |date=13 February 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826115038/http://www.easternpartnership.org/daily-news/2012-02-13/moldova-scraps-plans-hold-constitutional-referendum |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }} ===Third attempt=== On 13 March, Nicolae Timofti and MP [[Mihai Godea]], the leader of the [[Democratic Action Party (Moldova)|Democratic Action Party]] talked about the expected election and what would make Godea agree to vote for him.{{cite web |url=http://portal.moldpres.md/default.asp?Lang=en&ID=168680 |title=Non-affiliated Moldovan MP to decide on support for presidential candidate on 14 March |publisher=Portal.moldpres.md |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720195305/http://portal.moldpres.md/default.asp?Lang=en&ID=168680 |archivedate=20 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Two days later Godea announced his support for Timofti.{{cite web|url=http://www.inprofunzime.md/stiri/politic/godea-s-a-razgandit-va-vota-pentru-nicolae-timofti-maine.html |title=GODEA s-a razgandit! VA VOTA pentru Nicolae Timofti MAINE |publisher=Inprofunzime.md |accessdate=18 March 2012}} At the end of a meeting with Timofti on 14 March, Igor Dodon had not decided whether to back him.{{cite web |url=http://portal.moldpres.md/default.asp?Lang=en&ID=168749 |title=Moldovan Socialists need more time to decide on support for ruling coalition's presidential candidate |publisher=Portal.moldpres.md |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120712113111/http://portal.moldpres.md/default.asp?Lang=en&ID=168749 |archivedate=12 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Following meetings between the [[Alliance for European Integration]] and the [[Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova]], another election attempt was set for 16 March after parliament affirmed the date 9 days earlier, though PCRM boycotted the vote on the premise that the incumbent parliament is illegitimate, amidst their demand it be dissolved.{{cite web|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2012_03_07/67803958/ |title=Moldovan Parliament sets presidential election for March 16: Voice of Russia |publisher=: |date=7 March 2012 |accessdate=16 March 2012}} Three PCRM rebels, who called themselves "socialists," and led by Igor Dodon suggested they would back Timofti. Dodon said: "The election of a president is better than an aggressive campaign for new parliamentary elections which will not solve the political crisis. We must put an end to the crisis and get down to work for the good of the country. That is how an opposition should act and not choose to stage marches and street demonstrations." Timofti said: "The European orientation of Moldova must be a priority. This has been the policy of Moldova in recent years and this is the policy that must continue" and that "I am convinced that Moldova has no other future than a European future."{{cite web|author=RFE/RL's Moldovan Service |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/who_is_moldovas_new_president/24518350.html |title=Profile: Who Is Moldova's New President-Elect? |publisher=Rferl.org |accessdate=18 March 2012}} The vote was brought forward from the afternoon to the morning. PCRM also threatened to disrupt the vote. PCRM supporters protested the election, but former president Vladimir Voronin later said that the party had called for a suspension to the protests. ====Final result==== Timofti was elected with the support of AEI, three former PCRM deputies who had defected to PSRM and [[Mihai Godea]]. The head of the election commission, [[Tudor Deliu]], announced the result saying that "after 917 days, the epic of electing a president is over."{{cite news|last=Tanas |first=Alexander |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/16/us-moldova-president-idUSBRE82F19M20120316 |title=Moldova breaks political gridlock, elects president |agency=Reuters |accessdate=21 March 2012}} Addressing reporters after the [[Constitutional Court of Moldova]] confirmed him as head of state on 19 March, Timofti said that his inauguration would likely take place on 23 March.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/russia/detail/124552/ |title=Moldova's new president to be sworn in on March 23 |publisher=Kyivpost.com |date=16 March 2012 |accessdate=21 March 2012}} According to article 79 of the constitution, he must be sworn in as president within 45 days. {{electiontable|class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" Moldovan presidential election, 2011–2012}} '''Summary of the [[Moldova]]n [[President of Moldova|presidential]] election result''' |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#e9e9e9; vertical-align:top;"|Candidate ! style="background:#e9e9e9; text-align:center;"|Party ! style="background:#e9e9e9; text-align:center;"|Votes |- |[[Nicolae Timofti]] |Independent |62 |- style="background:#e9e9e9;" | align="light" style="vertical-align:top;"|'''Totals''' | style="text-align:right; width:30px; background:#e9e9e9;"| | style="text-align:right; width:30px; "|'''101''' |- | style="text-align:left;" colspan="8"|Source: [https://archive.is/20130415110852/http://politicom.moldova.org/news/moldovan-parliament-elects-president-ending-threeyear-deadlock-229103-eng.html Moldova.org] |} ==Reactions== ===Domestic=== Upon being elected, Timofti called for the removal of all Russian peacekeeping troops from Transnistria and said that he advocates a peaceful solution to the Transnistrian conflict through negotiations with the 5+2 format (Russia, Ukraine, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, the European Union and the U.S.{{cite web|url=http://www.georgiatimes.info/en/news/73264.html |title=New Moldovan President demanded Russia to withdraw its troops from Transnistria – News |publisher=GeorgiaTimes.info |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012}} He also called for reforms and upholding the "rule of law"{{cite web |url=http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052774.html |title=Moldova's news – Newly elected President pledges to ensure rule of law |publisher=Allmoldova.com |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722200010/http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052774.html |archivedate=22 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} adding that in his role as president and thus "guarantor of the constitution" he would "supervise how the principle of separation of powers in the state is observed as this is a fundamental, democratic principle without which we cannot speak about veritable rule of law. They now speak a lot about the imperfection of the constitution and the necessity of amending it...I will provide all the support for improving the constitutional framework so that there are no blockages in the future and the supreme law ensures the efficient and harmonious development of the country."{{cite web |url=http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052772.html |title=Moldova's news – Nicolae Timofti in favor of amending Constitution |publisher=Allmoldova.com |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120718181727/http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052772.html |archivedate=18 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} He was also congratulated by parliament.{{cite web |url=http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052766.html |title=Moldova's news – Moldovan parliament congratulates new-elected president |publisher=Allmoldova.com |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120718171338/http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052766.html |archivedate=18 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} The AEI also expressed regret over the PCRM's boycott with PM Vlad Filat saying the coalition has sought to "establish a civilised dialogue with the opposition Communists, but they refused to contribute to the efforts of the government. I wish I would have had half of the possibilities that the opposition has now, when I was in opposition. Once the president is elected, the political establishment will have to cope with the hardest burden – we should have a united society at the next parliamentary election, without the barricades that the Communists have built now."{{cite web |url=http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052763.html |title=Moldova's news – Moldovan ruling alliance regrets Communists' absence from presidential polls |publisher=Allmoldova.com |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720051747/http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052763.html |archivedate=20 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} However, PCRM MP [[Sergiu Sîrbu (politician)|Sergiu Sîrbu]] said the boycott will continue and that "something serious should happen for us to return to parliament, like the resignation of the president or of the government." He also added that a new law that would suspend salaries to those MPs who are absent from sittings of parliament or of parliamentary commissions without reason would not deter the boycott as "it will be a serious blow, but democracy and the fight for justice [would continue]."{{cite web |url=http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052776.html |title=Moldova's news – Communist MPs do not give up boycott |publisher=Allmoldova.com |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120718061923/http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052776.html |archivedate=18 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ===International=== *{{flag|European Union}} – The [[President of the European Commission|President]] of the [[European Commission]] [[José Manuel Barroso]] also congratulated Timofti on behalf of the EC.{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/12/196&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |title=Message of congratulations from President Barroso to Mr Nicolae Timofti, President of the Republic of Moldova |work=Europa (web portal) |accessdate=21 March 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.egovmonitor.com/node/48162 |title=Message Of Congratulations From President Barroso To Mr Nicolae Timofti, President Of The Republic Of Moldova |publisher=Egovmonitor.com |accessdate=21 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130122055818/http://www.egovmonitor.com/node/48162 |archivedate=22 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }} [[President of the European Parliament]] [[Martin Schulz]] congratulated Timofti saying he was "happy that the Moldovan people finally have a president after a two-and-a-half-year long institutional stalemate."{{cite web |url=http://enpi-info.eu/maineast.php?id=28343&id_type=1&lang_id=450 |title=Schulz welcomes election of Moldovan president to end 2.5-year stalemate |publisher=Enpi-info.eu |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826114048/http://enpi-info.eu/maineast.php?id=28343&id_type=1&lang_id=450 |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }} The [[European Parliament]]'s permanent rapporteur on Moldova Sir [[Graham Watson]] commented: "The Moldovan Parliament and the new President-elect Nicolae Timofti both deserve our congratulations. A three year political deadlock has finally been resolved. I welcome the emphasis that President Timofti has already put on European integration."{{cite web|url=http://www.grahamwatsonmep.org.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1408&catid=7&Itemid=157 |title=MEP Watson congratulates newly elected Moldovan President Nicolae Timofti |publisher=Grahamwatsonmep.org.uk |date=16 March 2012 |accessdate=21 March 2012}} *{{flag|Council of Europe}} – [[Secretary General of the Council of Europe|Secretary General]] [[Thorbjørn Jagland]] also congratulated Timofti.{{cite web|url=http://www.timpul.md/articol/felicitarile-curg-garla-nicolae-timofti-felicitat-de-thorbjrn-jagland-victor-ianucovici-si-victor-orban-32322.html |title=Felicitările curg gârlă! Nicolae Timofti, felicitat de Thorbjørn Jagland, Victor Ianucovici şi Victor Orban |publisher=Timpul.md |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2012}} President of the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|Parliamentary Assembly]] [[Jean-Claude Mignon]] issued a statement that read: "I am convinced... all the political parties will show responsibility by accepting the democratic legitimacy of the country’s institutions and hence the legitimacy of a president elected in accordance with its constitutional requirements." *{{flag|Georgia}} – [[President of Georgia|President]] [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] said the election was seen "as a victory for democracy and European values in Moldova."{{cite web|url=http://unimedia.md/?mod=news&id=45629 |title=Saakaşvili: Alegerea președintelui în Republica Moldova este o victorie a democraţiei |publisher=Unimedia.md |accessdate=21 March 2012}} *{{flag|Hungary}} – Prime Minister [[Viktor Orbán]] congratulated Timofti over a phone call on 16 March. *{{flag|Lithuania}} – President [[Dalia Grybauskaitė]] send a message to Timofti that read: "I would like to assure you that Lithuania remains fully committed to your country's endeavors towards integration into Europe."{{cite web|url=http://www.15min.lt/en/article/world/lithuanian-president-congratulates-german-and-moldovan-president-elects-529-204684#axzz1ph6D2Kd7 |title=Lithuanian president congratulates German and Moldovan president-elects |publisher=15min.lt |accessdate=21 March 2012}} *{{flag|North Korea}} – [[Rodong Sinmun]] reported on 30 March, "[[Kim Yong Nam]], president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, sent a congratulatory message on March 27 to Nikolai Timofti on his election as president of the Moldovan Republic. Kim in the message wished the president success in his work for the prosperity of his country, expressing belief that the bilateral relations would develop favorably". *{{flag|Romania}} – President [[Traian Băsescu]] congratulated Timofti over a phone call on 16 March.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5i0xLVWfPszBGvUtCY3QNMdTvz7XA?docId=55369b0ff9f1460badc4125f0c2f396b |title=The Associated Press: Moldova elects pro-European judge as president |publisher=Google |accessdate=16 March 2012}} The president then congratulated the [[Chişinău]] political class for reaching an agreement on the matter. Băsescu also assured Timofti of his full support for continuing the country’s internal reform processes and closeness to the EU{{cite web |url=http://www.bucharestherald.ro/politics/34-politics/31514-nicolae-timofti-new-president-of-moldova-basescu-congratulates-him-over-the-phone |title=Nicolae Timofti, new president of Moldova. Basescu congratulates him over the phone! |publisher=Bucharestherald.ro |date=16 March 2012 |accessdate=21 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120723102318/http://www.bucharestherald.ro/politics/34-politics/31514-nicolae-timofti-new-president-of-moldova-basescu-congratulates-him-over-the-phone |archivedate=23 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} and invited Timofti to visit Romania.{{cite web |url=http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052771.html |title=Moldova's news – {{Sic|hide=y|Newly|-}}elected Moldovan president receives congratulations |publisher=Allmoldova.com |accessdate=18 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120907190654/http://www.allmoldova.com/en/moldova-news/1249052771.html |archivedate=7 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }} *{{flag|Russia}} – Members of the lower house of [[Federal Assembly of Russia|parliament]], the [[State Duma]], welcomed the election of the president on 16 March. The chairman committee on [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] affairs and relations with compatriots, [[Leonid Slutsky (politician)|Leonid Slutsky]], said that "Moldova today has finally officially ended a long-term government crisis. Moldova is the world’s only republic which has lived so long without a president."{{cite web|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/en/c32/367991.html |title=Duma members welcome election of Moldova president | date=16 March 2012 |language=ru |publisher=Itar-tass.com |accessdate=18 March 2012}} *{{flag|Ukraine}} – [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] congratulated Timofti during a phone conversation on 16 March and also invited Timofti to visit Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/124422/ |title=Yanukovych congratulates Timofti on election as Moldovan president |publisher=Kyivpost.com |accessdate=18 March 2012}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Moldovan presidential elections}} {{Moldovan elections}} {{Alliance for European Integration}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moldovan presidential election, 2011-2012}} [[Category:2011 elections in Moldova|Presidential, 2011]] [[Category:2012 elections in Moldova|Presidential, 2012]] [[Category:2011 in Moldova]] [[Category:2012 in Moldova]] [[Category:Presidential elections in Moldova|2011]] [[Category:Cancelled elections]] [[Category:Indirect elections]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox military person |image=Glenwood 1st XV 1935.jpg |caption=Glenwood High 1st XV Rugby team, McGarr at top right |name=Clement Aldwyn Neville McGarr |birth_date={{Birth date|df=yes|1917|11|24}} |death_date={{Death date and age|df=yes|1944|4|6|1917|11|24}} |placeofburial= Poznan Old Garrison Cemetery, Poland |birth_place= [[Johannesburg]], South Africa |death_place= |nickname=Nev |birth_name=Clement Aldwyn Neville McGarr |allegiance={{flagicon|South Africa|1928}} |branch={{air force|South Africa|air force-1940}} |serviceyears=1940–44 |rank=Lieutenant |servicenumber=95691 |unit=[[No. 2 Squadron SAAF]] |commands= |battles=[[World War II]] * [[Western Desert campaign]] ([[POW]]) |battles_label= |awards=Mentioned in Despatches {{plainlist| }} |relations= }} '''Neville McGarr''' (24 November 1917 – 6 April 1944), was a fighter pilot from South Africa who was taken prisoner during the [[Second World War]]. He participated in the 'Great Escape' from [[Stalag Luft III]] in March 1944 but was one of the men recaptured and subsequently murdered by the ''[[Gestapo]]''.
==Pre-war life== McGarr was born in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa and moved with his family to Durban,<ref>[http://samilitaryhistory.org/7/07marnl.html SAMH Website – South African Escapers]</ref> in 1923. He began his education there but suffered with polio and was paralyzed from the waist down at the age of twelve. McGarr did not give up and working constantly he managed to recover the use of his legs and by September 1930 was able to start high school, he was educated at [[Glenwood High School (South Africa)]] from 1932 to 1935 and before graduating he had earned a series of awards for sports and academic achievement and was a member of the first XV Rugby team for his school.<ref>[http://www.glenwoodhighschool.co.za/node/4654 Glenwood High School Website – Neville McGarr]</ref><ref>[http://www.cwgc.org/education/imp_pop/pdf/rugby.pdf GlenwoodSchool Rugby team photo]</ref> He commenced work in the laboratories of [[Lever Brothers]] before moving to the Treasury Department of Durban Corporation. His hobbies involved his [[Rudge Special]] motorcycle and his [[BSA Scout]] sports car although he did complete a tour of duty with the naval reserve.<ref>Vance (2000), p.146-147</ref>
==Service career== After war broke out McGarr and two friends enlisted in the [[South African Air Force]] to train as pilots in May 1940. On 23 May 1940 his service commenced and on 26 April 1941 he was commissioned as [[second lieutenant]] having been presented with his pilot's brevet. He was posted to Egypt on 21 July 1941 and in October 1941 joined [[No. 2 Squadron SAAF]] flying Curtiss [[P-40 Tomahawk]] fighters over the Libya-Egypt frontier.<ref>[http://rapidttp.co.za/milhist/15/d15sepne.html SAMH Society Bulletin – Neville McGarr]</ref><ref>Vance (2000), p.147</ref> [[File:Royal Air Force Operations in the Middle East and North Africa, 1939-1943 CM2513.jpg|thumb|305px|A Tomahawk fighter of the SAAF in the desert.]]
==Prisoner of war== On 6 October 1941 flying with his squadron on a patrol in the Sidi Omar vicinity they were intercepted by a formation of [[Luftwaffe]] [[Messerschmitt Bf 109]] fighters of II Gruppe [[Jagdgeschwader 27]] and two [[P-40 Tomahawk]]s were shot down by [[Gustav Roedel]] and Otto Schulz.<ref>Shores (1969), p.56-57</ref> McGarr baled out, his wing mate was killed in action. He landed and set off on foot with only one shoe, the other having been lost. After three days walking through the desert without food or water he was captured by soldiers of the [[Afrika Korps]] and after only a few days in a prison camp in Libya was sent to Germany where he was held at [[Stalag Luft I]] [[Barth, Germany|Barth]] before being transferred to [[Stalag Luft III]] where he was an immediate volunteer for tunneling although his physical size made him unsuitable and he was asked to supervise the security teams maintaining a watch against German checks which might otherwise discover the tunnels.<ref>Vance (2000), p.147-148</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ehf0ESmep-8C&pg=PA182&lpg=PA182&dq=neville+mcgarr+saaf&source=bl&ots=WRDOZaf7RP&sig=mbx_S79XWInUnSZ_aD7TlrR3-RA&hl=en&sa=X&sqi=2&ved=0ahUKEwipxrbjybDJAhWBOQ8KHQsdAS0Q6AEIRzAH#v=onepage&q=neville%20mcgarr%20saaf&f=false Google books-In Gallant Company]</ref> [[File:Model Stalag Luft III.jpg|thumb|right|305px|Model of Stalag Luft III prison camp.]]
=='Great Escape'== McGarr was one of the 76 men who escaped the prison camp on the night of 24–25 March 1944, in the escape now famous as "[[Stalag Luft III|the Great Escape]]". When the Germans discovered the escape they began extensive well planned manhunts.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
Neville McGarr was briefly trapped in the tunnel due to his stature but was freed and escaped into the woods although on the afternoon of 27 March 1944 after surviving the freezing temperatures and blizzards he was recaptured with George McGill and taken to the civil prison at [[Żagań|Zagan]]. He was one of 19 men now recaptured and held there until moved to [[Görlitz]] prison where he was in a cell with Keith Ogilvie, [[Paul Royle]] and [[Charles Piers Egerton Hall|Chaz Hall]]. Early on the morning of 6 April 1944 [[Tony Bethell]] heard a truck arrive at the prison and heard six names being called out,<ref>Carroll (2004), p.250</ref><ref>Andrews (1976), p.50</ref> Denys Street, Neville McGarr, [[Jack Grisman]], [[Sandy Gunn]], Harold Milford and John F Williams were taken away.<ref>Vance (2000), p.267</ref><ref>[http://www.saafmuseum.org/research/research-articles/358-the-great-escape-from-stalag-luft-iii SAAF Museum – Neville McGarr]</ref>
He was one of the 50 escapers [[Stalag Luft III murders|executed and murdered]] by the ''Gestapo''.<ref>Read (2012), p.143</ref><ref>Andrews (1976), p.188-189 and p.207</ref><ref>Burgess (1990), p.271</ref> Originally cremated at Breslau by the [[Gestapo]]<ref>Read (2012), p.306</ref> and buried at Sagan, he is now buried in part of the Poznan Old Garrison Cemetery.<ref>[http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2194335/McGARR,%20CLEMENT%20ALDWYN%20NEVILLE Commonwealth War Graves Commission casualty – Lieut. Neville McGarr SAAF]</ref><ref>[http://www.pegasusarchive.org/pow/cSL_3_Fifty.htm Pegasus Archive – 50 murdered escapers]</ref>
McGarr is recorded on the official list published by the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]]<ref>[http://www.rcaf-arc.forces.gc.ca/en/article-template-standard.page?doc=commemorating-the-great-escape/hvhsqy96 RCAF Website with list of the 50 murdered officers]</ref> His name was amongst the 47 murdered officers named in the British press when the story became public knowledge on or about 20 May 1944<ref>Western Morning News, Dundee Courier and Yorkshire Post, 20 May 1944</ref><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/44291180/ Ottawa Journal, 20 May 1944, p.17 – listing murdered officers]</ref>
[[File:The50Memorial.jpg|thumb|305px|Memorial to "The Fifty" down the road toward Żagań, McGarr is on the right hand panel]]
==Awards== His conspicuous bravery was recognized by a [[Mention in Despatches]] as none of the other relevant decorations then available could be awarded posthumously. It was published in a supplement to the ''London Gazette'' on 8 June 1944.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=36544 | supp=y |date=2 June 1944 |pages=2645–2646 }}</ref>
==Other victims==
: ''See [[Stalag Luft III murders]]'' The Gestapo executed a group of 50 of the recaptured prisoners representing almost all of the nationalities involved in the escape.
Post-war investigations saw a number of those guilty of the murders tracked down, arrested and tried for their crimes.<ref>Vance (2000), p.209-210</ref><ref>Andrews (1976), p.217-220</ref><ref>Read (2012), p.288</ref>
{|class="wikitable" align="right" |Nationalities of the 50 executed |- |{{Flagicon|UK}} 21 British |- |{{Flagicon|Canada|1921}} 6 Canadian |- |{{flagicon|Poland}} 6 Polish |- |{{flagicon|Australia}} 5 Australian |- |{{flagicon|South Africa|1928}} 3 South African |- |{{flagicon|New Zealand}} 2 New Zealanders |- |{{flagicon|Norway}} 2 Norwegian |- |{{flagicon|Belgium}} 1 Belgian |- |{{flagicon|Czechoslovakia}} 1 Czechoslovak |- |{{flagicon|France}} 1 Frenchman |- |{{flagicon|Greece|old}} 1 Greek |- |{{flagicon|Lithuania}} [[Romualdas Marcinkus|1 Lithuanian]] |}
== References == ; Notes {{Reflist}}
; Bibliography * {{cite book|author=Ted Barris|title=The Great Escape|publisher=Dundurn Publishing |year=2014|isbn=1459728440}} * {{cite book|author=Simon Read |year=2012 |title=Human Game|publisher=Constable|isbn=978-1-4721-1262-0}} * {{cite book|author=Sean Feast|title=The Last of the 39-ers|publisher=Grub Street|year=2015|isbn=978-1909166158}} * {{cite book|author=Jonathan F Vance|title=A Gallant Company|publisher=Pacifica Military|year=2000|isbn=978-0-935-55347-5}} * {{cite book|author=Christopher Shores |year=1969 |title=Fighters Over The Desert|publisher=Neville Spearman|isbn=0668020709}} * {{cite book|author1=[[William Ash (pilot)|William Ash]]|author2=Brendan Foley|title=Under the Wire: The Wartime Memoir of a Spitfire Pilot, Legendary Escape Artist and 'cooler King'|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=quefAAAAMAAJ|year=2005|publisher=Bantam|isbn=978-0-593-05408-6}} * {{cite book|author=[[Paul Brickhill]]|title=The Great Escape|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KEWdJvOdZ2wC|year=2004|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-32579-9}} * {{cite book|author=[[Alan Burgess]]|title=The Longest Tunnel: The True Story of World War II's Great Escape|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sy3t5zLmXrYC|year=1990|publisher=Naval Institute Press|isbn=978-1-59114-097-9}} * {{cite book|author=[[Albert P. Clark]]|title=33 Months as a POW in Stalag Luft III: A World War II Airman Tells His Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5f2fAAAAMAAJ|year=2005|publisher=Fulcrum Pub.|isbn=978-1-55591-536-0}} * {{cite book|author=Arthur A. Durand|title=Stalag Luft III: The Secret Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aQdSPgAACAAJ|date=1 January 1989|publisher=Patrick Stephens Limited|isbn=978-1-85260-248-2}} * {{cite book|author=Allen Andrews |year=1976 |title=Exemplary Justice|publisher=Harrap|isbn=0-245-52775-3}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130303171346/http://www.mmpubs.com/catalog/lessons-from-history-c-4.html ''Project Lessons from the Great Escape (Stalag Luft III),''] by Mark Kozak-Holland. The prisoners formally structured their work as a project. This [https://web.archive.org/web/20150925130225/http://lessons-from-history.com/node/33 ''book''] analyses their efforts using modern project management methods.
{{DEFAULTSORT:McGarr, Clement Aldwyn Neville}} [[Category:South African Air Force officers]] [[Category:South African World War II pilots]] [[Category:World War II prisoners of war held by Germany]] [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:South African military personnel killed in World War II]] [[Category:Participants in the Great Escape from Stalag Luft III]] [[Category:South African escapees]] [[Category:Extrajudicial killings in World War II]] [[Category:South African military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:South African prisoners of war]] [[Category:People from Johannesburg]] [[Category:People from Durban]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]]

'''Njimi''' was the capital of the [[Kanuri people|Kanuri]] state of Kanem (later [[Kanem Empire|Kanem-Bornu]]),<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = African Civilizations: Precolonial cities and states in tropical Africa: an archaeological perspective|last = Connah|first = Graham|publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 1987|isbn = 0521266661|location = Cambridge}}</ref> north of [[Lake Chad]], from the 11th through the 14th centuries. Founded by the [[Sefawa dynasty]] in the 11th century, the town dominated [[trans-Saharan trade]] in [[ivory trade|ivory]] and [[Arab slave trade|slaves]] between the central [[Sahara]] and [[Libya]]. The precise location of Njimi has yet to be determined.<ref name=":0" />
== References == <references />
[[Category:Destroyed cities]] [[Category:History of Africa]] [[Category:History of Chad]] [[Category:Bornu Empire]] [[Category:Former populated places in Chad]]
{{Chad-stub}}

{{for|the international concept of providing periodic access to buildings usually closed to the public|Doors Open Days}} [[File:Open House Day 2014.jpg|300px|thumb|Open House Day 2014 at [[European Southern Observatory]]{{cite web|title=Programme for The Long Night of Science 2015 Available|url=http://www.eso.org/public/announcements/ann15046/|accessdate=24 June 2015}}]] An '''open house''' (also known as '''open day''' and '''at-home day''') is an event held at an institution where its doors are open to the general public to allow people to look around the institution and learn about it. These are often held at [[schools]] and [[universities]] to attract prospective students, familiarize them (and their parents) with the facilities, allow new students to become familiar with facilities and meet others, or to open informal communication channels between school staff and the students and their parents.{{cite web|title=Open day|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/open-day|website=Collins English Dictionary - Complete & Unabridged 10th Edition.|publisher=HarperCollins|accessdate=25 January 2015}} ==Open houses in American schools==
School open houses are about two hours long, the length of a good movie or show . . . a well-executed event sets the stage for a successful [[school year]]. The face-to-face meetings with families help build relationships, increase the visibility of the parent group, and develop a [[sense of community]] at school.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | vauthors = | title = Make Your open house a Hit | work = | publisher = PTO Today | date = | url = https://www.ptotoday.com/pto-today-articles/article/1413-make-your-open-house-a-hit | doi = | accessdate = 2016-03-27 }}
Contrary to what its name might seem to imply, an open house at the average school is not intended for general members of the public, but rather, specifically, for the parents and family members of the students who either attend or are considering attending a school. In the overwhelming majority of [[Education in the United States|schools in the United States]], open house is held once a year, typically in the first month or first quarter of the [[school year]]. It is common for open houses to be held in the evenings or weekends, to allow for parents who work during the standard the [[work-week]] hours to attend, but holding open house in the daytime is not unusual, especially at elementary schools. ===Elementary schools=== In [[elementary schools]], open houses often have no schedule; parents come and go during the scheduled hours as they please, and some teachers may be willing to discuss individual students' progress with their parents. Some schools may schedule displays of [[school activities]], such as a performance by a [[Children's Choir|student choir]]. ===Secondary schools=== In [[secondary schools]]—divided into [[middle schools]] (also called junior high schools) and [[high schools]] (also called senior high schools)—the single most important purpose of the open house is to allow parents and teachers meet each other face-to-face. In many middle schools and high schools, parents are given a schedule, often the same schedule their child follows during the school day. The parents go from one class to another, in the sequence that their child attends them, usually in the very same classrooms. Typically in such open houses the parents have only 5–15 minutes with their child's teacher, which provides time for the teacher to explain their class expectations, but not enough time to discuss individual children. ==See also== * [[Cultural festival (Japan)]], school open days in Japan ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== For examples of open houses as informative events, see the following: * https://www.ptotoday.com/pto-today-articles/article/1413-make-your-open-house-a-hit *[http://www.opendays.com/ A university and college open day directory in the United Kingdom] {{Schools}} {{DEFAULTSORT:open house (Common School Event)}} [[Category:Canadian culture]] [[Category:American culture]] [[Category:Social events]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Women murder victims to [[:Category:Female murder victims]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 November 4]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = "Peaches" | image = File:Peaches tattoo.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Tattoo | birth_name = | birth_date = 1967 - 1981 (aged 16 - 30) (approximate) | birth_place = | disappeared_status = {{Unidentified for|1997|06|25}} | death_date = {{circa}} June 25, 1997 | death_place = | death_cause = Homicide | body_discovered = June 28, 1997
[[Lakeview, New York]], United States | other_names = Girl with the Peach Tattoo | known_for = | height = Unknown | weight = Unknown }} '''Peaches''' (also known as "'''Girl with the Peach Tattoo'''" or as '''Jane Doe No. 3''') is an unidentified female whose torso was discovered on June 28, 1997 in [[Lakeview, New York]], near [[Hempstead Lake State Park]]. The cause of the woman's death is listed as [[homicide]], apparently by [[decapitation]]. {{As of|2018}} she remains unidentified since her skull has yet to be found.{{cite web|url=http://archive.longislandpress.com/2010/07/01/long-islands-unidentified-murder-victims/|title=Long Island's Unidentified Murder Victims|work=Long Island Press|accessdate=15 October 2014}} The woman had a tattoo on her left breast depicting a heart-shaped peach with a bite taken out of it and two drops falling from its core, which resulted in her nickname.{{Cite news|url=https://www.longislandpress.com/2016/12/13/unidentified-murder-victim-dubbed-peaches-linked-to-gilgo-beach-killings/|title=Murder Victim Dubbed 'Peaches' Linked to Long Island Serial Killer Case|last=Bolger|first=Timothy|date=2016-12-13|work=Long Island News from the Long Island Press|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en-US}} {{as of|2016|December}}, additional skeletal remains found on Long Island in 2011 have been positively identified as belonging to Peaches, along with the remains of her child.
